DayZ as a concept is amzing in it's own right, however in practice it has constantly hit speed bumps which halt its momentum in a way which is extremely evident. It seems as though the creators are more interested in adding content rather than having the game be playable for those who've purchased it. The fact that this game has been in early access for nearly three years is utterly shocking. The workrate of the creators is not near what it should be with so much crowdfunding from just the early access. However there is still much fun to be had, in it's current state DayZ is a stripped down version of the mod that so many people stumbled across and loved. Every fibre of my being wants me to reccomend this game but I simply can't, not yet.

You'd think after a literal decade in early access the game would surpass it's not-so-standalone mod predecessor in every way.

However, as it so happenes the opposite is the case. The entire game is an unstable bug ridden mess, from CTDs on startup over zombies bugging through doors to visual glitches, this game's got them all.

Besides all the new bugs and instabilities all the fancy new functions take away from DayZs core experience which made the mod so great. All this crafting and base building isn't helping it's slowing the game down, making it boring gindy.
As someone who's played the original mod and DayZ standalone when it first released I'm increadibly let down.

Don't waste your money on this, play the mod instead.

With 1600+ hours in this game. You can tell at a glance that I enjoy it.  However, I could not advise a newcomer to buy this game and invest this much time into it simply because of the state the game is in at this time. 

Yes, I understand its early access, however, the game should be progressing and not regressing particularly with the zombie AI. The game could improve by 50% if they just removed zombies altogether and had an "end of time apocalypse ."

The game has its highlights, but at this point you can get the same gameplay and MUCH BETTER performance from other games such as Arma 3, and H1Z1. 

I would suggest the newcomer to skip this for now, and check it out again once it is out of early access. That way they can be sure to know if Bohemia came true to their word on improving this, or they could find out that Bohemia instead took the money they have made already and ran.

VERDICT: Fun game but pass for now until more improvements come to it.

Started playing this in 2013, not understanding a damn thing and annoyed by the buggy mess.
Until 2024 i have over 500 hours on official servers who are capped at 60 players. Felt a bit too empty as a loner. 

In 2024 i finally have the launcher working for modded servers. Go to parameters -> profile name -> ''Mister X'' .
Then go servers and select the modded server you wanna play on and download the addons. 
Playing on 90+ servers now, with more loot difference, dogtags when a player created his character etc. Server performance is even better then officials. 

For 10 years loot is life, and the thrill of meeting an enemy player with that loot is never shown in any other survival game.

This was originally a mod for a game called Arma 3 (made to be a realistic military simulator) but due to its popularity turned into a standlone game. Since then devs are constantly updating and adding new things to this amazing game. Its a survival game, very, very realistic. Its set in a fictional part of Soviet Union or Russia called Chernaurus. There are no quests, no missions, nothing... In that sense the game is very simple, your only goal is to survive. How ? By any means neccesary. How long? As long as you possibly can. 
Its one of the best, if not THE best, survival game on the market. altho its not begginer friendly.

I loved the DayZ mod from Arma 2 over ten years ago, and assumed this would be a really polished and modernised version of the same. I really wanted to like it. 
Unfortunately it feels like playing the mod from over ten years ago! I'm sure there are mods for this game which make everything better, but I certainly don't want to go over the refund playtime limit finding out. 

As an example, rooms have wardrobes, fridges, cupboards etc, none of which can be opened or interacted with. Anything you can pick up is just on the floor. The itinerary system is also not intuitive. 

On the plus side, the second person I bumped into spoke to me in Russian for several minutes before killing me, which may have been my fault as I accidentally gestured 'cut throat' instead of waving at them.

20 HRS in and it is getting boring already. Lot of server hopping to find areas not already looted. 

Lots of running through fields or forest hoping to find a town. No in game map so usually not totally sure where to go.

The game isn't really hard, you just need to be lucky and get spawned in were it hasn't already been looted. It almost always has so you need to run somewhere else hoping it isn't empty too or server hop.

I think if you are playing with a bunch of friends on a private server that has the loot boosted it might be fun.  Especially if you have all day to play.

But I seem to spend a lot of time on loading pages as a casual solo player. Not a lot of game time doing anything but running.

Not a lot changed after 7 more hours, but, the loot seemed less absent so I assume they have shortened respawn time. Stuff like water bottles & rocks are still just painfully slow to find. Melee combat rather jerky so it feels off.

This game is timeless no matter how much time passes it will always provide such unique interactions and situations. The game feels technical until it isn't you can go from playing for 2-3 hours with no contact with other players then that sense of security starts seeping in,you let your guard down rounding the 8th town that looked the same not expecting anything because it's been easy sailing,then suddenly you hear violent gunfire erupting at you. They are too far to accurately land multiple hits but YOU are hit. You run duck to cover not sure of anything scrambling for a sense of stability as you treat your wounds. SITUATIONS LIKE THESE are what I crave the unpredictability.

SIDE NOTE: Wish the devs added more content to the game the game is already great but the lack of upkeep and content is a little disheartening considering the success of the game.

Where do I start with DayZ? It's fun, it's infinitely replayable, and it has a thriving community. DayZ is first and foremost a survival game...when you first start playing. For your first probably 8 hours you will be lucky if you find 6 or 7 people, and you will probably end up starving to death, getting ganked by a gang of zombies, torn to shreds by wolves, or get a seemingly incurable disease that causes you to throw up, but then eventually goes away but you are dying of thirst (because of the throwing up), so you go and drink a bunch of water from a water source that looks really crystal clear, but then you realize that your food bar is low, so you go and kill, skin, and cook a chicken that you find, then eat said chicken, only to realize that your hands were covered in blood so you get sick from that, but luckily you had the right items to cure it so you are a-ok! Then you realize the water you drank from was actually not clean and end up getting sick from that and then suddenly realize that the wolves that you had escaped from earlier ended up chasing you and are now camping outside the building you are in, so you run away to a town and end up getting shot by a random guy who now has to deal with a pack of wolves. In other words, DayZ is brutal. DayZ is unforgiving. DayZ doesn't tell you anything. DayZ forces you to sit down and use the god damn sun to figure out which way is which and-

Ok let me compose myself. That was a pretty good description of the first 10-20 hours of DayZ for the average player. You run around lost and confused, but still have fun because you know, deep down in your bones you are actually making progress. So lets talk about the next 80 hours of play. DayZ disguises itself as a zombie survival game, with building, farming, fishing, hunting, etc. but do you want to know what DayZ really is? DayZ is a psychological horror multiplayer shooter game. Let me set the scene.

It's nighttime, and you are in the east side of NWAF (That being the NorthWest AirField) and you suddenly hear a shot coming from VERY close by. By very I mean right outside the building you are looting. You quickly swap to your gun, but you realize its not fully loaded. You quickly swap to a full mag and wait and listen. You hear footsteps stomping around. You are on the second floor, hiding in a room with 2 windows. You don't know if this player is alone but you do know that they most likely can-and will-kill you. You hear the sound of the 1st floor door open and go to prone in front of the closed door of your room. You wait as the player runs around, opening doors and looking for loot. You hear him run up the stairs and ready yourself. He opens the door and you hold your breath and fire, landing a clean headshot, dropping him. You stand up, walking over to loot the body an-he was naked. No items on him, no nothing. You hear a quiet "crack!" and your screen goes dark. This was a real encounter I had within the game, and it had turned out that the player had a friend in the ATC tower not far from the building I was in who was ready to snipe me. When you reach a certain point of the game the main emotion you feel is anxiety. At any moment someone could end you. Someone from 1500 feet away could just so happen to see you and drop you at a moments notice. Someone could be hiding in a bush as you run up to go and loot that hunting stand that they placed a bear trap at the foot of. Someone could be gunning down the road at 40 mph in a Gunter and flatten you on the pavement. DayZ is a game of constant death and rebirth. It is the ultimate feeling of "Am I being watched?" and the answer, 9/10 out of 10 is no, you aren't...but it doesn't matter, because that 1/10 means you need to constantly be on alert. No lights, no gunfire unless absolutely necessary, and no, and I repeat NO glowsticks. The thing I see people do all the time is they throw their glowsticks on their backpacks at night because its "too dark out wah wah wah", DONT DO THAT. That is like a beacon to anyone with so much as a god damn revolver. DayZ players are like moths, they see a light in the dark they go to it. 

Thanks for reading my DayZ short story, please buy and play this game immediately so you too can feel like a PTSD stricken Iraq veteran!

once upon a time in the magical land of uwu, where rainbows danced and fluffy clouds giggled, a phenomenon known as "uwu" emerged, spreading joy and adorableness across the digital realm. Uwu, a term derived from cute anime expressions, has become a language of its own, transforming ordinary sentences into delightful expressions that warm the heart.

In the enchanting world of uwu, words are sprinkled with extra love and affection, creating an atmosphere of sweetness and innocence. The journey begins with a simple "hewwo" instead of the traditional "hello," immediately setting the tone for a whimsical adventure. As we delve deeper into the uwu-speak, we encounter endearing phrases like "nyaa~," "pwease," and "notices ur bulgy wulgy," each contributing to the charm of this delightful linguistic landscape.

Uwu is not just a language; it's a feeling, a sensation that wraps around you like a cozy blanket made of marshmallows and rainbows. When faced with a challenge, the uwu spirit encourages us to "nyuzzle" through difficulties, replacing stress with a positive, uplifting energy. Uwu, with its magical powers, turns frowns into smiles and transforms even the gloomiest days into a pastel-colored wonderland.

Communication in the uwu realm often involves the generous use of "owo" and "UwU," symbols of wide-eyed adoration and admiration. Whether expressing excitement about a new adventure or sharing a heartfelt sentiment, the uwu language adds an extra layer of sweetness that resonates with the gentle rustling of cherry blossoms in spring.

One cannot escape the influence of uwu without encountering its adorable mascots - cute, fluffy creatures like kittens, bunnies, and pandas. These uwu ambassadors frolic in meadows of positivity, spreading happiness and warmth wherever they go. In the uwu world, even the most mundane activities, like sipping on a cup of tea or reading a book, become kawaii adventures filled with uwu magic.

As we navigate through the uwu-scape, it's essential to embrace the spirit of innocence and playfulness that defines this extraordinary language. Uwu teaches us to approach life with a childlike wonder, finding joy in the smallest of things and celebrating the beauty of simplicity.

In conclusion, the wondrous world of uwu invites us to express ourselves with a sprinkle of magic and a dash of cuteness. It's a realm where kindness reigns supreme, and every interaction becomes a delightful journey through fields of uwu blossoms. So, dear reader, may your days be filled with uwu joy, and may your heart forever resonate with the enchanting melodies of the uwu language.

And jeebus the amount of hiking you do in this game is ridiculous.  

And this is from someone who loved flashpoint, who played the hell out of it. My favourite was to go off mission, sneak into a russian army base, steal a Shrike or Hind and just go to town on the enmy. 

Day-Z is just bat shit boring. Do not waste your money on this crap

The problem is that it seems incredibly unlikely to be able to find the initial tools so that you don't starve to death right from the start. To make a fire you need small stones. Even these are mostly not there. I once found a fishing rod, but died before I could find something to dig up worms for bait. And so it goes, endlessly re-spawning, looking for something to keep you alive, and dying. Every 15 minutes.

Changing review to recommended, with the caveat that you need to play on a community server. It feels like the official servers are where you will starve and freeze to death every 15 minutes.

"우린 한 외딴 마을에서 처음 만났어요. 처음엔 어색했지만 곧 우린 둘도 없는 친구가 되어 함께 마을을 누볐죠. 그러던 어느날, 좀비를 쏠려던 저의 탄에 친구가 맞아 다치게 됐어요. 우린 웃어 넘겼죠.  다치고 허기진 우리는 먹을 거리와 약을 구하기 위해 다른 마을을 찾아 떠났습니다. 가파른 산을 넘고, 좀비 떼 들을 지나쳐서 결국 마을은 찾은 우리는 어서 집에 들어가 약을 찾기 시작했죠. 그때, 경찰 좀비가 우릴 향해 왔어요. 한 마리 뿐이라 총을 쓸 필요가 없었지만 전 어리석게도 한발 발사해버렸습니다. 마을에 있던 모든 좀비들은 저희들이 있던 집으로 달려오기 시작했고, 문을 닫기도 전 몰려든 좀비들을 향해 총을 발사했지만 이미 너무 늦어버린 후였죠. 문을 다 닫고 확인해보니 친구는 너무나 크게 다치고 난 후 였습니다. 가망이 없는 걸 알게된 친구는 자살을 택하였습니다. 순식간에 다시 혼자가 된 저는 바닥에 널부러진 좀비와 친구의 시체를 한참 바라봤습니다. 허탈하더군요. 너가 없는 세상은 살아갈 의미가 없구나, 실수로 너를 쐈던 총의 총구가 이젠 내 입을 향한다."  19/02/2024

I used to play DayZ mod since nearly day one. I used to LOVE it, it was great, the community was incredible, game was original as f**k and I lived awesome experiences at this time with it.

Then they released the Standalone, of course I bought it 10 minutes after the release. I was totally hyped about this game after enjoying many many hours playing the mod.

What happened next? nothing. They screwed it up using the Arma engine, this engine is not ready to move DayZ as it should. The devs increased the team members but they are developing the game the same way than a monkey uses a pc. One steps up and three steps down. 

Alpha? yeah sure that's a great excuse. The team leader (Dean Hall) decided to leave the project at the end of the year, why? well I guess that he is not ready to asume that his game is not going to advance in a good way so better to step away.
Brian Hicks? doing non-sense streamings where you need to pay 5$ if you want to subscribe to his channel. Yeah you don't really need to do it to be aware of his streamings, but it's only about principles. Man, you are making pay 5$ to your, already, customers in order to show them how do you play that shitty game and you don't even answer basic questions that they do in your chat. But hey, I guess that this is because you don't even know how to develop a game so answering basic questions about it makes your life pretty hard.

Anyway, I wanted this game to be the best game ever, but I guess that it will be a decent game only when the modders will be able to mod it, the future of this game is in their hands.

I don't really need to talk about hackers, bugs, etc. because there are enough people talking about them, and what they say in general is the reality of this game.

Don't buy it, at least until 2016.

Edit on 2019: Don't buy, at least until 20XX

Edit 2024: Bugs aside, the best survival experience in the market.

this game is super close to ideal.... quite possibly the closest any developer has ever come...... my limited complaints for this game are just silly stuff like - the game is massive but i cant realy hide... were ever you try to set up shop its going to stick out like a P P in a disney movie... the base building is just a wall that can be a wall or a door that anybody with 15 minutes of free time can easily overcome... like rust theres a pure focus on offense while severely limiting what ya can do to defend or hold out.... in any survival game especialy zombie games that is whats missing... yes you scavenge and struggle but you cannot fortify and you cannot hide... i think thats because the majority of players only have an hour to play and in that hour they need to be able to ruin someone elses 4 days of effort or theyll play something else... thats the market that disposes income like there is no tomorrow.... finacialy speaking it makes sense to give them what they want but as you see here the wolves slaughter all the sheep and the sheep have no incentive to return.... and the game stays on the brink of totaly dead

Hands down the worst survival game out there. You either die of hunger, thirst or some type of infection before you can find anything that will let you actually progress in the game. In my 4 hours of playing I only found a single frying pan, I had no idea there were pots in the game until going on Youtube. How are players supposed to survive if finding the absolute basics for survival are next to impossible to acquire. I am not asking for hand holding, I liked how independent the game is, but there just are not enough basic loot items. 

Like just add more of the absolute basics to spawn areas. Plastic water bottles that only have a small amount of water left, more canned food that only feeds you a small portion, more basic heals so when you get an infection you can actually heal yourself. 

The game is literally unplayable in the current state and the servers are proof of that, Majority of servers are sub 10 people. 

At least make it so squads can spawn close to each other so my friend and I do not waste half an hour IRL trying to reach each other only to die to hunger when we meet

DayZ as a base game is a joke, developpement team is one of the worst in the industry, many issues due to EGO from managing team (many reports on that if you want to check, i mean its pretty known). BUT, because of players and passionnate developpers with less skills for the most part than the developpement team but with better brains and better ideas, have transformed this game in modded servers. There so much diverse proposition, SO FAR away from the base vanilla experience that sucks hard and hasn't move that much in 5 years.

So i dont recommand the game itself but the community that worked hard to upgrade their shi**y game. Ones of the best modding community out there with the Escape From Tarkov SPT modding community and the ones from Stalker GAMMA. So keep that in mind, you will have to take time to test servers, to find the best ones, download hundreds of the Gigas of mods for the most complete ones, before enjoying great games with great communities. See the 39.99€ as a access cost to those servers, cause Vanilla is really, REALLY, trash. That much trash that it hurts me to give a recommandation of DayZ and let this shitty management team take the pat on the shoulder when it should be modders that worked so hard for free. 

Review is over, but here is a little story for people interested in :

People see them as real Bohemian Interactive, but the real team for BI as always been focus on ARMA and are doing a fantastic job there for many reasons, DayZ Team is the shi**y part with managers that listen their EGO and who fired really competent developpers with awesome ideas that u see in other games cause their ideas were for the most part so much better than the managing team and their EGO saw them as danger cause so far away from their level of competence. To talk about one example in mind, see Road To Vostok ? This insane loot dispersion mechanic ? Where the solo developper made the loot kind of spawn in a grenades in middle of rooms and then blow up before player comes in and so loot is disperse randomly behind furnitures, in corner of the rooms, NOT LIKE DAYZ where loot is put in so unatural places. So this idea he took from a ex DayZ developper that wanted to put this genius idea in DayZ, but it was not the boss developper idea so even if it was a pretty genius idea, he forced him to work on the shit*y loot disposition we always knew in DayZ. This  is one example. End of the story, i felt like it was important to insist on the modders community of DayZ being the reason of the success and not the DayZ official team. Cya !

So after re-reading my re-read review, I've surmised that DayZ is one of the most well balanced games to ever exist, i only have 469 hours and its still nothing to the amount that you will find in both pvp and pve, im still learning alot of stuff, basebuilding keeps changing, server rules differ from server to server, and there is just a crap ton of good communities out there that will teach you all you need to know.

Survival Experience: DayZ offers a highly immersive survival experience set in a post-apocalyptic world where players must scavenge for resources, manage their hunger and thirst, and fend off threats like zombies and other players.

Player Interaction: The game emphasizes player interaction, creating opportunities for alliances, betrayals, and emergent storytelling as players navigate the dangerous landscape together or against each other.

Open-World Exploration: DayZ features a vast open-world map with diverse environments to explore, including cities, forests, and military bases. Exploring the world can lead to discovering hidden loot, encountering unique locations, and uncovering the game's lore.

Risk and Reward: The game's permadeath mechanics and high-stakes PvP encounters introduce a constant sense of risk and reward. Every decision matters, whether it's choosing to engage in combat, trusting other players, or deciding where to scavenge for supplies.

Base Building and Crafting: Players can construct bases to establish a safe haven, store loot, and fortify their position against threats. Crafting allows players to create tools, weapons, and gear to enhance their survival chances in the harsh environment.

Dynamic Events: DayZ features dynamic events such as helicopter crashes, supply drops, and infected hordes that add unpredictability and excitement to the gameplay experience.

Modding Support: The game offers robust modding support, allowing players to customize their experience with user-created content, including new maps, gameplay mechanics, and assets, which can extend the game's longevity and provide diverse gameplay options.

Community Interaction: DayZ has a dedicated community of players who contribute to forums, create content, and organize events such as PvP tournaments, role-playing servers, and cooperative challenges, fostering a sense of camaraderie among players.

After playing the DayZ Mod for Arma 2 for many hours back in the day, I wanted to support this standalone game by Bohemia.  I just loved the open world of Chernarus with its forests, towns and villages, and the survival mechanics of the game, which have you scavenging for food, shelter and equipment while avoiding the infected.

However, it's a pretty brutal game, and death can come at any moment from another survivor or the harsh game world.  When it happens, you are back to square one with nothing.  This generates a lot of tension, as well as memorable moments.  I remember carefully scoping out one of the airbases (where some of the best loot can be found), and then slowly making my way towards it, only to get shot by a sniper from the control tower.

This game is and always will be "The game".  I've played games for my entire conscious life, and many legendary games have come and gone, but DayZ is forever.  

The only issue I have with DayZ is that I don't have more time to play it.  There are no quick dopamine hits here like with PubG or other shooters, but what you get here is eternally memorable moments.  You'll remember fun little teamups and difficult firefights years after they happen.  Hundreds of hours in, you'll still be honing your skills and having to adapt to changing circumstances.  

Not for the faint of heart, but like with other difficult at first games(Such as the Soulsborne games), perseverance is rewarded

Introduction:
DayZ, the epitome of zombie survival games, has been a staple in the gaming community since its inception. With its immersive world, challenging gameplay mechanics, and intense gunplay, DayZ offers a truly unique experience in the survival genre. However, like any game, it has its flaws. In this review, I'll delve into the aspects of DayZ that make it both exhilarating and frustrating.

Aspects I Enjoyed:

Immersive Gameplay:
DayZ's greatest strength lies in its ability to immerse players in a post-apocalyptic world where survival is paramount. From scavenging for resources to avoiding hostile players and infected, every moment in DayZ feels tense and realistic. The open-world environment is beautifully crafted, offering a vast and diverse landscape to explore.

Punishing and Challenging:
Surviving in DayZ is no easy feat. The game is unforgiving, with harsh consequences for mistakes and poor decision-making. Food and water are scarce, diseases can quickly debilitate your character, and the threat of other players looms constantly. This level of challenge adds to the game's intensity and keeps players on their toes at all times.

Rewarding Progression:
Despite its difficulty, DayZ offers a sense of accomplishment unlike any other game. Every successful scavenging run, firefight, or interaction with other players feels like a small victory. Progressing from a helpless survivor to a well-equipped and skilled survivor is incredibly rewarding and keeps players coming back for more.

Amazing Gunplay:
Gunplay is one of DayZ's standout features. Firearms feel weighty and realistic, with each shot carrying significant consequences. The sound design further enhances the experience, immersing players in the chaos of combat. Whether engaging in a firefight with other players or fending off infected, the gunplay in DayZ is both thrilling and satisfying.

Aspects I Didn't Enjoy:

Janky Movement:
While the overall immersion of DayZ is impressive, the movement mechanics can feel clunky and unresponsive at times. Character animations can be awkward, leading to frustrating moments during intense encounters. Improving the fluidity of movement would greatly enhance the gameplay experience.

Lackluster AI Zombies:
One aspect of DayZ that falls short is the behavior of the infected. While they pose a significant threat in large numbers, their AI can feel simplistic and predictable. Adding more variety to their behavior and making them more intelligent would make encounters with infected more dynamic and engaging.

Limited Environmental Interaction:
In a game focused on survival, it's surprising that players cannot interact more with the environment. Specifically, the inability for zombies to break down doors feels like a missed opportunity. Allowing infected to pose a threat even within fortified structures would add an extra layer of tension to gameplay.

Conclusion:
DayZ remains a standout title in the zombie survival genre, offering unparalleled immersion, challenge, and reward. Its intense gun play and unforgiving game play mechanics keep players engaged for hours on end. While it has its flaws, such as janky movement and lackluster AI, the overall experience of DayZ is truly exceptional. For those willing to brave its harsh world, DayZ offers an unforgettable journey through the apocalypse.

Bohemia Interactive should get a lawsuit for deceiving players all these years with this game. Although some things implemented are good, the majority of the things are bad. The game is in an OK state but lightyears away from being complete, mostly for all the missing content, bugs and recurring broken promises of their so called "roadmaps" throughout the years.

After years of development (still on going) the game is now enjoyable and pretty good fun! Play it as an one time adventure, expect to die and have no gear fear. In my honest opinion the base building sucks (at least at the time of writing this review) and you should not waste too much time doing it. Sometimes it might be fun to stash food, weapons and ammo in a box somewhere but anything bigger than that will feel like a waste of time once your base gets raided.
One of the best parts are the human interactions in the game, so make sure you have a working microphone. Also very active modding community keeps the game alive, so be sure to check out the different maps and mods there are.

I have never been as excited to play a game as I was to play DayZ when I first heard about it around 5 years ago. I can honestly say that it is a “good” game as it stands today. However it falls short of its potential in many ways but I hope Bohemia Interactive will put more love into it over the years and I can guarantee the team that those efforts would not be wasted. The community fell in love with this game a long time ago and love seeing it improve.

What I would suggest is putting love into the official servers where many players end up and make them the best experience possible and even more desirable than some of the incredible modded servers where the true value of this game rests. If you guys do that I would shocked if you didn’t see a vast uptick in sales and a reinvigoration of the community that loves this game so much and has stood by it through thick and thin. Thank you for all the effort you’ve put into such an interesting and fun game!

Edit: I've played this game for almost 1900 hours now. I've been spawn camped, base camped, raided, looted, taken prisoner, executed in front of my team mates, and done the exact same thing to other people. I've spent countless weeks grinding for gear on community servers with friends I've made from across the globe, to get the best possible armor and guns to outfit myself and my team. I've crushed people with helicopters, handcuffed and tea-bagged players after breaking their knees. Beaten men to death with a hammer for a can of bacon. Forged friendships with people, through gunning down poor freshies for the clothes off their back. 

This is a game that no-one truly loves, we all just have a slight degree of self hatred to play this game for days on end, logging dozens, upon dozens of hours a week, hundreds of hours a month. 10/10 would recommend this game to everyone I meet.

i was having one of those moments in the game where everything was just so real. It was dusk, a little bit foggy, and I was walking by myself through the forest. I could hear somebody. stalking me. Got to a clearing I saw what it was. It was a. wolf I thought he'd would leave  me, but that's not the case. Followed me. Started biting me. and I found safety. on a half wall from one of those ruined houses. Since I was bit, I was bleeding and I. did not have any bandages left, so I took off my shirt, cut it up for rags. And as I did that, they fell to the ground right next to the wolf. Now the wolf was just sitting there waiting for me. He was not gonna leave and I was bleeding to death. So as a very desperate. last chance to save my life. I jumped on him. And started stabbing with my knife. and I killed him.  Well, all seems good. except for the fact that I had my headphones on and I. am living in a hotel  30 minutes later. It was a knock on my door. Damn, it sounded like a cop knocking on the door. I look to the people and sure enough, there's three officers. I opened the door. and acting really funny. Asking me Questions. and then the officers said," well, there's no way to put it other than someone called and complained that you had killed somebody". It's a big mistake. And then about three or four minutes into that conversation, it dawned on me. that during that wolf incident, I was probably a little louder than I should have been screaming." I killed it. I killed it."  And then I invited him into the hotel. He took one look at my PC and said Yep, big mistake.

*Original Review* (This review was within the first two weeks of launch. Things have since, progressively gotten to a state of disgust.) This game is amazing. Tons of potential to be had here. *Edit 1* After well over a year of waiting for something to happen to the goddamn zombies, I have decided to thumbs down. They keep adding more muddled shit into the game to keep the retards in the player-base flooded with useless items. Fix the goddamn zombies. The developers ran off with the communities money and blew it on hookers cocaine and a trip to Nepal. This is just sad had so much potential but due to bad development choices and Dean Hall taking the money to the top of Mount Everest and throwing it over the side. Only to then slip and slide down the side of it Scrooge McDuck style over the loot.

*Edit 2* Please rename this game to DAY you assholes took out the Z.

*Edit 3* 12/30/15  - Decided since DayZ has been out for an eternity I would try it again. Fired up just fine only to find there are maybe 4 servers total that are visible ? It's 2:47 EST and there isn't an open slot anywhere. So what now you have to rent a server just to even be able to play this ? Heard there were Zombies back in and was going to check them out. Unable to do that. Used to bug report and such but pretty much most bug reports were ignored. All in all unsure how this game will turn out at this point. On one hand it could be relabled and sold as the most dangerous hiking simulator in existance! On the other it has soured its people by allowing things to get this dire. I still hope I will wake up and one day this game will be better than the mod and completely blow me away but I am starting to doubt it. So much potential and most of it will probably be wasted.

The interactions with players absolutely make this game. All depends on the server you're in. 

10 years in the making. 

"I want a game, that is not a game" - Dean Hall.

Just give me a map and compass, bro. 
The world is POINTLESSLY big. I run miles going fuck-knows-where just to find a can of vegetables, as I'm looking for literally any indication of which way goes inland. You know, the part of the map where you can actually find supplies worth a shit. 

Nobody plays this game to get lost. Your "realistic aspect" of dropping me into a huge ass world with zero means of navigation sucks. "The sun rises in the East and sets in the west bro, just watch the sun!". Maybe diarrhea should start shooting down my characters leg every time I eat a half-moldy granola bar because it's "realistic". Maybe my character should get constipated because it's "realistic". Maybe my character shouldn't be able to see straight ever, hopelessly depressed and disassociated in a completely fucked world because it's "realistic".

Are you fucking kidding me? What am I Bear Grylls? What's the premise of the game again? I thought I was here to fill backpacks with stuff and engage other survivors but I am literally just trying to figure out which direction takes me towards actual loot after being spawned in the middle of bum**** hills actual miles from anything interesting.

Not fun. If this is fun for you, you have way too much time on your hands. On what planet is it fun to be dropped in a 142-sq mile map and just "expected" to find your way around?

Wow. Very realistic, guys. You should add a feature to put the half-broken makarov I found after five hours of scavenging in my mouth and pull the trigger when I'm bored as hell and can't be convinced to trek another five miles to find anything that isn't useless. 

This "game" isn't a game. It's a part-time job that manages to somehow be less entertaining that my actual, day-to-day IRL job. It is literally more enjoyable to get in my car (Yeah, my real car) and drive to work for a shift than to play this game.

1/10. Don't buy this. You'll get more dopamine just having your friend drive you into the middle of the actual woods and dumping you out with a single can of green beans and a bandaid with no means of navigating your way back to the main road.

One of the craziest and most influential games of all time, DayZ was originally a mod for Arma 2: Operation Arrowhead.  By lineage of this game, you can trace back the success of most modern first person shooters. DayZ lead to clones such as WarZ, Infestation, and most importantly H1Z1. Soon after, H1Z1 introduced a new game mode that began to rapidly outpace any competitors in the field, the Battle-Royale. And the rest is history. 

DayZ itself however has been anything but left behind. Instead of switching to the money-making formula that it helped grandfather after a failure of a launch, they stuck their nails in the dirt and got to work. DayZ today is THE zombie apocalypse simulator, and even as new DayZ-like gamemodes pop up around such as the extraction-shooter, DayZ continues to run with a strong community of players. 

The quality of the simulation is beyond anything I've seen to date in a video game. The complex crafting system relying on the word-of-mouth of players themselves straight out of a real apocalypse movie, (although you'll most likely learn most of your crafting skills through youtube videos) the way real life knowledge of astronomy can help you navigate the maps (since the stars that are out at night are all in their accurate real-life positions), and dynamic player interactions leading to Tarantino-quality stories being written in the moment. 

I've never known what it means to EXPERIENCE a media product like all the Christmas movies advertise. But DayZ is an experience. Thousands of experiences. You will meet cannibal death cults. You will meet dying people who will stick you up and steal your blood so that they can inject it into themselves. You will meet apocalyptic taxi services. You will be followed by hordes of zombies only to have shots ring out and the zombies fall one by one, and when they are all dead you will look around and never meet your savior. You will meet all these people, you will become these people. This is DayZ- this is your story.

To anyone considering purchasing, I would personally recommend finding a good community-lead server. I personally play on Survival of the Fittest, which takes place on a community-made map called Namalsk, but if freezing to death every ten minutes isn't your thing, Chernarus is the perfect beginner map.

This game does not inspire joy, nor is it very engaging. I guess someone could say the game is "difficult" because there's hardly any resources around, but it's not difficult; it's just boring. 

I'm running around while listening on Discord to what my friends are doing 10 kilometres down-coast. Them coming to meet me isn’t really worth anyone’s time, because they’re going towards a direction of scarcity, while they themselves are struggling to find any food.

There is no groups in the game. So, from the 4:30 hours I spent playing the game, I really spent 4:10 hours holding Shift-W, only to be annoyingly interrupted by the hunger or thirst systems. Maybe 15 minutes was spent listening to my friend struggle to figure out how to cook a piece of chicken while I was eating a burger IRL, and the other 5 minutes was spent where we finally met up, one friend died of starvation (or food poisoning?), despite having eaten three chicken fillets mere 3 minutes ago.

Next I died a couple of minutes later, because we were again hastily B-lining to their new spawn location, except I was wet due to running in rain previously. Don't get wet in this game, because it'll undo you faster than any zombie can hope to. Maybe the rain is radioactive; I don't know, it's not explained.

The various systems surrounding hunger/thirst/stamina are superficially interesting and I’d even say a step in the right direction, but—just like me and my friends—are 10 kilometres away from emergent gameplay mechanics. You eat 3 chicken fillets (called steaks), only to be dying of hunger some 15 minutes later. The characters run out of breath after running for about 20-30 metres (might be a sprint, but still), and there’s no way to improve your character’s meagre stamina.

There’s a good layer of complexity with the cooking and crafting system, but it feels like that sucked all the creative juices out of the team.

Melee combat, which is the only thing available to you—unless RNGesus looks upon you and spawns you near a gun or some bullets—is incredibly janky. Zombies clip through you, and their AI is so dumb you can either not fight them or just glitch them and kill them.Engaging with the zombies is largely a waste of time too, since you’re not rewarded in any way for doing so.

The UI leaves a lot to be desired for. Sometimes you can’t arbitrarily equip or unequip things, it requires a weird “shuffling” dance before it lets you swap gear (and I don’t mean moving inventory items, that system in itself is fine). The game doesn’t tell you why you can’t equip things, other than a red border, but the border is sometimes green and you still can’t equip things.

World interactions are inconsistent. Some bushes you can break for branches, some you can’t. You kinda develop a half-intuition for which bushes you can interact with. There’s a rubble of rocks, and there’s a singular rock that can be picked up from it to be used as a weapon (similar to rocks on tracks). Some rocks have a 3D model that elevate them from the texture (there is no normal mapping in the game as far as I can tell, which is bizarre for a game released in the past decade), but you can’t tell if you can interact with the rock or not; mostly the answer is no, but there’s the occasional special rock that you can pick up. Seems arbitrary.

Ladders are extremely buggy. I died a few times because the character refused to interact with a ladder to go down. Sometimes it works, but most of the time it does not. Crouching doesn’t help, inching forward slowly doesn’t help either (that’s how I died). You can spam the interact button until your finger rots off.

Now, don’t get me started on doors. They just yeet you when you open them. Sometimes they half-clip you through a wall, and then your camera starts shaking so much that the game should have an epilepsy warning for this thing alone. This makes interacting with the door sometimes nigh impossible, because the interact prompt just keeps getting shaken off the screen. So you’re left shaking your mouse and spamming the interact button while praying it sticks.

Tl dr: everything about this game feels less than half-baked, and unseasoned.

Sure, play the game... learn to win by 'surviving,' get addicted to scavenging and hiding, and have some fun with the very choppy pvp frame rates, non-registering shots from weapons, lack of real base building construction, poor sound simulation, glitching AI, and horrible connectivity issues using vehicles... oh, and yes, lots of hacking. 

But, do NOT ever expect this game to be anything more than it already is. It's now a cash cow for Bohemia to make 6+ more modern games... and rebuild it's primary ARMA game (as of Jan 2024).

It's a very old game (SA released 2018) that gathered over 267+ million USD gross revenue to date, on Steam alone (vginsights dot com> game> 221100). But Bohemia has yet to rebuild its dual (graphix/physics) architecture onto a more modern and stable single engine platform. Modern games also use browser platforms to keep cheating down, but not dayz.

Bohemia would rather build 6 different newer games with all that money rather than deal with the primary issues of the Dayz. Cheating, bad internet timing, and AI/player glitching (which is part of internet timing).

And that's why I don't recommend this very old game... So many other games have advanced past this one in terms of skill and quality for pvp looter shooters, like Tarkov for one (even with all Tarkov's hackers). And Dayz mod'ers are producing more quality content than the company itself. Which Bohemia seems to be content to add only old weapons and backpacks previously taken out, or taken from ARMA/Vigor games. But that's just my very old guy opinion, and I know there are big fanboys of Dayz to argue otherwise.

Is the Arma engine...an aquired taste? Yes. Yes this game has bugs, and can be janky from time to time.

...however, the apocalypse experience of DayZ is beautiful.

I have been playing for almost 2 years and i have watched this game change from a pretty glitchy survivor game to a beautiful masterwork of a sandbox survival game. It is challenging, but this brings the fun. You end up craving to learn and go again and again into the frey of what adventure you are looking for. There is PVP, PVE, and in each you can do your own roleplaying with different characters. You can live to help others, be a lone hunter, be a bandit, be a cannibal, tank up as a soldier, go light as a sniper, scavenger, form a team... ect. This is the best game for replay-ability and with the added maps and mods on DZSALauncher, there is just so much you can do. If you run out of things to do then you lived to 1 million. The game is harsh and unforgiving, but this makes it the most rewarding game out there for the things you accomplish, and the stories you get from your experiences are truely one of a kind. I would rate this 10/10 as a game and i would of paid more for it than i did, which i would never say about another game. If you read a bad review on this game it is when it was not from someone who played it recently. Check it out, it is worth it! Edit: Almost at 2k hours and its still the best game out there! Official servers are where its at.

DayZ is an incredibly challenging survival game that truly tests your ability to adapt and endure in a harsh, post-apocalyptic world. The game offers a plethora of options in its survival simulator, making each playthrough a unique and unpredictable experience.

The difficulty level of DayZ is not for the faint of heart. From scarce resources and relentless zombies to hostile players, every decision could be a matter of life or death. The game's steep learning curve adds to its appeal, rewarding players who invest time in mastering its intricacies.

One of DayZ's standout features is the thriving community. The game's open-world environment fosters player interactions, both cooperative and confrontational. Joining forces with others is essential for survival, but trust is a rare commodity in this unforgiving landscape. The social dynamics create a rich and dynamic experience that goes beyond the game's mechanics.

Realism is at the core of DayZ's design philosophy. Whether it's the need to manage your character's health, temperature, or nutrition, every aspect feels grounded in reality. This commitment to realism extends to the game's environmental details, providing stunning vistas and a meticulously crafted world that truly immerses players in the post-apocalyptic setting.

Graphically, DayZ delivers impressive visuals, especially when it comes to the expansive landscapes and atmospheric effects. The attention to detail in the environment, from abandoned towns to dense forests, enhances the overall immersion. While character models and animations may not be cutting-edge, the overall aesthetic contributes to the gritty and authentic feel of the game.

In conclusion, DayZ is a game that demands dedication but rewards players with a uniquely challenging and immersive survival experience. The diverse gameplay options, active community, and commitment to realism make it a standout choice for those seeking a true survival challenge in a post-apocalyptic world.

On a balmy afternoon, Ringoding, a character as vibrant and lively as his name implied, and I embarked on an impromptu exploration through the bustling streets of the city. With his infectious laughter and penchant for adventure, Ringoding led the way to a quaint boutique that beckoned with its eclectic display of garments. The air inside was a melange of fabrics and the soft hum of conversation, providing a fitting backdrop for our spontaneous escapade.

As we navigated the racks of clothing, Ringoding's eyes gleamed with excitement when he spotted a kaleidoscopic array of T-shirts. Each one seemed to tell a unique tale through its design, and amidst this riot of colors, Ringoding's enthusiasm bubbled over. Suddenly, he halted in front of a particularly eye-catching T-shirt, adorned with a whimsical pattern that mirrored the spirit of our camaraderie. Without missing a beat, he insisted that I try it on, convinced that it was destined to become an emblem of our shared moments and inside jokes.

The shirt, with its vibrant hues and quirky design, seemed tailor-made for our friendship. Ringoding, ever the spontaneous soul, didn't hesitate to declare it a must-have addition to my wardrobe. His insistence on purchasing the T-shirt for me was not just an act of generosity but a testament to the unpredictability and warmth that defined our friendship. As I left the boutique adorned in this unexpected gift, I couldn't help but reflect on the serendipity of the moment – a tangible symbol of the day Ringoding, with his boundless energy and keen eye for the extraordinary, wove another colorful thread into the rich tapestry of our enduring friendship. (i love you ringoding)

I originally posted a review for DayZ back in early 2014 when I bought it. It was just a one-liner review so I figured after 1000 more hours I would be a good time to actually write a in-depth review of this game.

Even though I bought it back in 2014, I actually only really started to play DayZ in 2017. The game used to be a bit too barebones back in 2014. I completely forgot about this game and noticed it somewhere in my library. Figured I would try it again.... From that moment on I was hooked.

DayZ had a lot of changes, mainly with the partial engine change in 2018. But I am not going to write chronoligical story on this game. Let's jump into what makes this game so damn good.

 [b] World design / Graphics [/b]

From all the open world PVEPVP survival games DayZ hands-down has the best world design. This is something that Bohemia as a company is so good in. it is the same for their other game series called Arma. It really feels like an actual world and not like a game. The way the hills are situated, the tree lines, water streams and little village down in that valley. Similar games such as Deadside, Scum or Miscreated all cannot come close to how authentic the world of DayZ looks like. 

Of course it is not perfect. This becomes noticeable in cities and some buildings. Cities feel a bit empty. There is little on the streets in terms of objects like crashed cars, trash or other things you would expect in an apocalyptic world. Some building are also very empty which impacts the immersion

Graphically the game does lack behind in some regards. The character models all look pretty good and so do all the new assets that have been added in the game over the past 5 years. Sadly there is also quite some objects and buildings that are still from the Arma 2 era (2009) that look way too ugly and really need to be replaced.

Certain graphical effects such as lightning or weather effects also do not always look as good as the competition. This is since the map is still stuck on the old engine (and will remain that way) and has limitations on the more modern graphical features.

Overall the game has great world design and decent graphics. I personaly hope they will increase the graphical quality of various objects and upgrade some of the more lacking parts of the world design.

 [b]Gameplay [/b]

In DayZ you can hunt, fish, farm and loot to survive. You can also craft various items, build a base and repair broken cars so you can drive around. Of course the main gameplay loop is to loot to find better gear and food/drinks to survive. PVP is a big part of the game as well.

The game can be a bit unforgiving in the beginning as there is just a simple tutorial page and some tips on the loading screen. Best is to watch some Youtube video's if you do not want to be thrown in the deep.

The map of chernarus is big (225 square KM) and the map of the DLC Livonia is just a bit smaller. You can play for hours without seeing anyone and out of nowhere run into someone in a dense wood in the middle of nowhere. This randomness is what makes DayZ so fun, in my opinion. It is not for everyone though. As I said, you can play for hours and do not encounter any other player. And if you are really looking for that pvp it can feel a bit empty from time to time.

With that being said, there are tons of community servers that have mods or no mods. Besides the fact that the game offers room for various playstyles (servers with more loot, traders and various new items), you also often see community servers that have upped the player count so player interaction is increased.

 [b]PVE [/b]

Pve in DayZ consists of fighting against the infected and animals. There are wolfs and bears that will attack you. The wolfs track you when you get into a certain range and will attack in a group. Bears are strong but not aggresive. They usually attack when you get too close. Fun thing is when you do not shoot the bear and it knocks you out, it will leave you alone most of the time.

Infected can be found in any place with human structures. Villages, cities, military bases etc... Right now I would say infected are the biggest issue in the game. Their pathfinding is okay at best and they often glitch around you or get stuck in you. However, the devs have mentioned that in 2024 they are looking into improving the infected. What this actually means is unknown at the time. Even though the infected have their issues, they are pretty well done in other regards. They respond to sounds (like throwing stuff or opening doors), you can lose them by running around corners and when you hide in a house they become calm again after a while. Have to say that the infected AI of DayZ is one of the better that I have seen in its genre. If the developers fix the pathfinding, animations and other earlier mentioned issues, they will become actually great.

Modifié 5 : 23/01/24 : 
pas mal d'évolution puisque j'ai passé pas mal de temps sur Livonia : une ambiance très différente de Chernarus, plus rurale, et toujours autant de chemin à parcourir à pied, sauf si on se procure rapidement une voiture...
La base principale est à Sobotka, une autre base à Topolin, et des tentes et barrils disséminés dans différentes villes pour stasher le loot qui devient souvent volumineux. 
J'ai ajouté quelques mods, légers, qui par contre simplifient bien ma vie de joueur, l'un d'entre eux permet
de porter un dos ghillie tout en bénéficiant de 150 espaces...très très cool. 

Modifié 4 : 07/11/23 : 
après mon "indigestion" des premières 1000 heures j'avais laissé tomber DayZ pour me consacrer à autre chose...
J'y suis revenu il y a quelques jours, pensant trouver le même jeu répétitif que j'avais laissé et...il est toujours répétitif, mais mon état d'esprit dans le jeu a totalement changé, je joue de manière très différente, avec des vues sur le jeu beaucoup plus satisfaisantes pour mon coeur de joueur :)
Le but est toujours de survivre mais les tactiques apprises au fil de l'expérience accumulée ont considérablement changé mon évaluation des situations, beaucoup plus complète et "construite".
Beaucoup plus précise et rapide alors sont mes actions...
Donc toujours Chernarus, toujours en Lan, avec quelques mods qui vont bien, un peu plus de munitions, un peu plus de silencieux, une voiture mais toujours pas de moto...ça serait top !
Chernarus est devenu un pays légèrement plus vivable, même si, comme je l'ai constaté hier tout peut partir en vrille de manière très rapide si l'on devient un tantinet trop confiant ou trop "insouciant"...
Il faut le constater, ce n'est pas la destination qui compte mais le chemin que l'on parcours, et surtout la manière dont on le parcours...
Ok, je vais surement aller sur YouTube faire des vidéos avec le titre "un joueur avec 2000 heures...", lol.   

Modifié 3 : 28/06/23 : 
au bout d'un peu plus de 1000 heures j'ai acquis l'expérience 'base', revenant après chaque update vers mon lieu habituel de résidence et reconstruisant (mais je fais en sorte maintenant de garder mes données 'joueur'...). J'ai commencé à adapter certains fichiers à mon style de jeu, ajoutant également un mod 'munitions', rendant le loot plus facile et faisant de Chernarus une carte plus homogène. Les 'Tiers' 1,2,3, 4 se comprennent mais vont à l'encontre d'une carte 'random' où l'on peut trouver un peu tout un peu partout. Ca n'encourage pas le joueur à rester et prospecter près de la côte et ses alentours , ce qui est dommage... Au fil du temps meilleure connaissances  des armes et de leur munition, et, après quelques accidents malheureux (lol) j'ai pu garder une voiture, ce qui évidemment change la donne, même si le but est d'aller à un endroit et d'explorer ensuite à pied le dit endroit, je connais encore si peu la carte ! DayZ ressemble donc de plus en plus au jeu dont j'ai envie...Certaines manipulations ou animations de jeu compliquant inutilement le gameplay pourraient être modifiées ou supprimées, la gourde qui ne se remet jamais à son emplacement sur la ceinture en est un exemple, où ce solide gaillard de joueur incapable de monter une simple marche en étant accroupi, petits détails qui cassent un peu l'ambiance...
Après ces mille heures DayZ devient un jeu où il peut faire bon vivre...

Modifié 2 : 28/04/23
200 heures, c'est le temps qu'il m'a fallu pour bien connaître les nécessités, contraintes et erreurs de la survie...Toujours en LAN, toujours  sans mods, et vraiment aucun envie de changer. Je viens de m'apercevoir que, pour l'instant, je ne mémorise pas les routes, mon esprit n'en a sans doute pas envie. Ceci dit la carte de Chernarus fait 300 Km2, il faudra un moment pour en venir  à bout, même avec une bonne carte.
J'ai déjà pu looter 2 hélicoptères mais c'est assez décevant, comme pour le reste du jeu le matériel est vraiment trop disparate, on a le fusil mais pas les munitions...ou l'inverse @@
Je construis une base, un endroit d'où rayonner ensuite mais il faut trouver des clous...pas gagné !

Modifié 1 : 22/03/23 : j'avance un peu dans le jeu, je construis petit à petit les connaissances nécessaires à la survie, il y a deux paramètres qui sont faibles et auront du mal à passer ce sont les pîèces vides et uniformes et la nécessité de les parcourir  encore et encore...on voit bien qu'on est dans de la programmation...boring !

Origine : 18/03/23
Voila, voila, après avoir regardé moultes vidéos j'ai décidé d'acheter le jeu pour avoir une idée claire de ce qu'il est... Paysages somptueux, carte (Chernarus) intéressante mais l'ambiance du jeu et les paramètres du gaming sont, pour moi, à la très proche limite de ce qui est acceptable...et que je n'ai pas accepté.
 
Le ressenti du débutant : la plupart des "joueurs" se comportent comme des c.h.i.e.n.s, ce qui fait froid dans le dos, et le gaming rend votre survie très improbable au-délà de 30 minutes et il faut  
 courir...courir...courir...courir......pour mourir !
Ce n 'est plus un survival c'est l'entraînement au marathon, le vrai, celui où le soldat grec meurt à la fin :D
J'ai été tellement choqué, "Mais enfin c'est un survival, tu comprends pas", que j'ai installé un serveur LAN pour régler déjà le problèmes des toutous, mais le jeu est toujours aussi épuisant, même des joueurs ultra-confirmés le disent...
J'ai l'intuition que les serveurs 'community', avec l'ajout massif de mods, sont un moyen de contourner le problème...qui vivra verra, j'en incorporerais sans doute certains quand je les connaîtrais...

Fantastic survival game.

Vanilla is a good game, however it is lacking on several features and additions that would make it a lot nicer to play, such as additional vehicles, better base building, maps, NPC's etc which can all be found on modded servers. This is why I always play modded servers and run one myself as the community for this game is insane with what they have created over the years. 
Modded servers are all very different and provide very different experiences however you can always find something your looking for, whether it be hardcore PVP and survival or just some relaxing PVE and farming, you can do it.

Want to spend your days fishing, how about exploring, or maybe you want to jump on a server with a train and just ride the train all day, or perhaps you want to make a mobile base with said train and assert your dominance over the server, sure you can do that in DAYZ modded. The skys the limit!

I would also to like to mention that the devs are still actively updating this game, Yes updates aren't super frequent but they try their hardest to fix bugs and give us new content without charging us additional fee's for every bit of content they create like most modern games and its not full of dumb cosmetics that some survival games seem to think its ok to sell now.

Overall I would 100% say this game is worth picking up, I have managed to rack up nearly 1000 hours playing this game on and off over the years and for what the game sells for versus the hours its a great investment. 
Most AAA titles will only give you 100 hours of game play if your lucky and we spend a lot more money on them and still receive a buggy mess these days. Where is this game started as a mod and look how far its come!

DayZ is probably one of my favourite games. I have 2k hours on the Xbox version and hope to get as much if not  more on the steam version. The adrenaline you get from firefights, the sense  of loneliness and paranoia you get from exploring Chernarus, Livonia and the countless modded maps that you can access for free. The anxiety this game gives is immeasurable. I have the best run yet (12h survived on official and counting), but i was starting to think this game is quite boring in the late stage. I had not met a player for about 6 hours and was starting to think i shouldn't play official. But then an adrenaline peaking moment happened. 

While going on a loot run in the city a guy jump scared me in a hospital. He started blasting his ak at me. He hit me but thankfully my plate carrier saved me. I started shooting back, but he started to close the door. While i was regaining my bearings i heard a horde of zombies approaching us. I ran in the nearest house planing my next course of action. At this moment i was breathing irl like i just swam a kilometre. I decided to push him as i concluded he was still in the hospital. Opening the door i saw his lifeless body on the floor... I had shot him through the door. My heart slowed down and i could enjoy the fruits of my victory.

From the moment he shot at me to the moment he died was a couple of seconds.. If my aim was worse or my weapon holstered i would be dead.

Edit. So after being rejected for a refund and accumulating almost 1k in this game I will elaborate on the issues. It is one buggy fucking nightmare of a game. The mods are fun to play around with, but still limited for anything to happen in this massive world of absolutely nothing. The pvp is dull in the official servers so unless you join in on a server with others that have them dedicated you're shit out of luck. There is no pve that would be considered worth the purchase at full price so wait for a sale. Each town has the same loot, and the zombies are less than enjoyable after a while to go around and shoot. Play this game while drunk and you'll have more of an enjoyable time. 

The updates that have occurred have not made this game any better in anyway. They usually create more bugs in the game than previously. The devs for this game are the wish version of Bethesda only you discover this after a few updates that have been released. Save you time, energy, and money with this title. If you are looking for a game that is a glitchy nightmare version of the long dark then this game is perfect for the casual fuck that you are. 

Being said there are some positive aspects of the game for a very casual player. Trying to keep yourself alive, creating fires, and cooking are some interesting features this game does have to offer. Getting sick from contaminated water or being too cold at times makes for a challenge that will be short lived. This game has huge potential but holy fuck add some shit into this massive world of literally fuck all sweet nothing. Walking simulator at best. But hey, at least you can find some dumb as fuck shit to wear while you explore the wilderness prior to discovering how hard you've been fucked by buying this game.

I first became aware of the DayZ mod back in 2013 when it was riding a wave of popularity. Despite this, I was never really able to get into it. The Arma 2 engine's clunkiness was a significant barrier for me. That changed when the standalone version of DayZ was released. In 2014, I bought and installed the game, spending several months immersing myself in its unique survival-based environment.

The game was unlike anything I'd experienced before. It featured a sprawling 200+ km² map depicting a desolate yet eerily familiar world. Engagements with other players were infrequent, yet the constant threat of violence was always looming. Resources were sparse, and the drive of each player to get their hands on what you had—even if it meant resorting to killing—added an intense level of excitement.

I played the game both solo and with friends, but after some time, I began to notice that the issues with the engine hadn't fully been resolved. Dying to a game bug posed a greater risk than an in-game gunfight. The excitement of discovering a new item was tempered by the shortage of interesting loot, and what items were available often didn't present a real challenge to obtain. This meant they felt somewhat unrewarding, as you could simply hop onto various deserted servers and gather everything you needed. The persistence of collected items was also non-existent.

Hearing that the developers were shifting their focus to creating versions for PlayStation and Xbox was disappointing. I felt this decision diverted precious resources away from developing new content, fixing bugs, and overall game improvement. Eventually, I had to come to terms with the fact that DayZ's lofty ambitions might have been too much to realize fully. Recognizing this, I decided it was time to move on from the game.

Years passed, and I kept a casual eye on DayZ's progress, always holding onto the slim hope that things might improve. However, when I learned that Brian Hicks—the original creator of the Arma mod—had fully left the studio and had stopped all involvement with DayZ, it felt like the final nail in the coffin. It was time to release any remaining hope I had clung onto. The game seemed to be nothing more than a beautiful but unattainable fantasy.

That was until a few weeks ago when an old friend of mine reached out and suggested we reinstall the game and see if it had improved. The current gaming landscape was, and still is, rather barren. I was completely disillusioned with gaming—every new shooter felt lackluster and tedious, just more of the same recycled concepts. In light of this, I figured, why not give DayZ another try? What was the worst that could happen? Maybe I'd lose an hour of my time and then carry on as usual.

We opted for an official server restricted to first-person perspective, logged into the game, and began to play. I fully expected to grumble and complain the whole time and then abandon the game an hour later. Surprisingly, the exact opposite happened. Instead, I found myself thoroughly engrossed, playing for an astonishing 65 hours over the course of just two weeks.

The initial impressions during the first hour of gameplay were a mixed bag. The game immediately felt more challenging, with survival being a tougher task. We had to learn a few tricks just to avoid starving, dying of thirst, or being overwhelmed by zombies. DayZ offers no hand-holding; it doesn't explain shit to you. You spawn into the game without a clue of your location, with jack shit to your name. There is no clear direction on what to do or how to proceed. To find your bearings, you must rely on your basic school geographical knowledge, and us a topographical map to navigate. Sometimes, you may even spawn at night, where darkness is so absolute that adjusting contrast, brightness, or any other fancy ass black equalizing settings on your expensive monitor won't make a difference.

As you venture forth, you decide your own path. You explore and loot various buildings, discovering items, clothing, and if you're lucky, some food. You learn how to engage and kill zombies without sustaining injuries, either by stealthily avoiding them or dispatching them strategically. It's through these experiences that the game starts to click, drawing you into its unparalleled immersion. Crafting in DayZ is intuitive and grounded, devoid of the over-the-top and unrealistic mechanics found in other survival games like Fortnite or Rust where you can slap wood together and build cringe castles. Instead, you can craft improvised backpacks using rope, sticks, and burlap sacks. You can fashion a fishing rod from a stick, rope, and a knife or any sharp object at hand. As you become more adept, the initial fears of hunger and thirst fade, replaced by an ability to adapt to the wilderness and its elements. Even the once-ominous howling of wolves in the night loses its frightful grip.

You begin to understand where the valuable loot can be found. Eventually, you accumulate an excess of supplies, prompting the need for storage. Suddenly, you have a goal: constructing a rudimentary shelter to safeguard your ill gotten gains, just in case you meet an untimely demise and have to start the arduous process all over again. Then you discover the immense depth of crafting options and small details. You realize that bullets can deflect and penetrate objects, that sunglasses shield your eyes from the sun's glare, and that you can bury a box as a hidden stash, like some kind of a pirate. The learning process becomes endless, yet every new piece of knowledge brings immense enjoyment.

By the end of a day, you come to the realization that DayZ is what you make of it. DayZ is patiently camping a military base for hours, dressed in a ghillie suit that you crafted yourself, on a hill, 400 meters away. DayZ is a simple pleasure of catching a fish in a forest lake and cooking it over a fire in the dead of night, all while shooting the shit with your mate on Discord. DayZ is having your heart pounding with excitement during intense firefights in the middle of nowhere. DayZ is the rush you get from discovering an exceptionally valuable piece of loot, like Night Vision goggles. It's a game where you craft your own unique story with each playthrough.

Over time, I came to realize that the tremendous effort put in by the developers is finally paying off. The numbers on Steam charts and the positive trend in player base affirm this. The "idea" of DayZ is alive and thriving, and the game is no longer a fantasy.

DayZ is a masterpiece in the survival genre, offering an unparalleled experience of post-apocalyptic realism. The vast open world is both hauntingly beautiful and perilous, setting the stage for intense encounters and unpredictable player interactions. The game's attention to detail, from realistic survival mechanics to authentic environmental design, immerses players in a world where every decision matters. With a constant stream of updates enhancing gameplay and introducing new challenges, DayZ keeps its community engaged and invested. The feeling of accomplishment when surviving in this unforgiving landscape is unmatched, making DayZ a must-play for fans of true survival experiences.

DayZ is hands down one of the most intense survival games out there. From the get-go, it throws you into a post-apocalyptic world that's hauntingly beautiful and eerily realistic. Chernarus, the game's setting, is a masterpiece of desolation, with abandoned cities and dense forests that make you feel like you're really in the thick of it.

What sets DayZ apart is the way it lets players shape their own story. Every interaction with other survivors is a wild card, and you never know if you'll end up making an ally or facing off against a foe. The game nails the whole survival thing, forcing you to scavenge for supplies, manage your hunger and thirst, and deal with both the undead and hostile players. The constant fear of losing everything keeps you on your toes, making every decision a do-or-die moment.

The crafting system is a game-changer. Building shelters, crafting weapons, and even farming to stay alive add a whole new layer to the gameplay. It feels damn good to see your progress and adapt to the challenges the game throws at you.

But where DayZ truly shines is in its multiplayer. Meeting other players, teaming up, or getting into intense shootouts—it's a rollercoaster of emotions. Trust is a rare commodity in this world, and the camaraderie and betrayal make every playthrough feel like a unique experience.

The devs have been on the ball with updates and fixes, showing they're committed to making the game better. Sure, it had its hiccups in the beginning, but the current version reflects the dedication to refining the player experience.

In a nutshell, DayZ is the real deal when it comes to survival games. It's tough, it's thrilling, and it's endlessly rewarding. If you want a game that puts you through the ringer and leaves you with stories to tell, DayZ is a must-play that sets the bar high for the genre.

UPDATE:

Well I would be a hypocrite if I did not update my review. I've more than doubled my hours on this game. I can't help myself. I still want to rage quit all the time due to perma-death, but I always come back. So many servers with many unique options there is something for everyone. Nothing like walking around, constantly being terrified that you're going to lose all your stuff. Even better when you have a large friend group that likes to spend time walking towards eachother as well. Bohemia has continued to spend time patching this game and it continues to improve. I'll say it again, Good Luck, Survivors!

OLD REVIEW:

Wow...I have had so much hope for DayZ for years. So much...I love the concept of the game, the ability to collaborate with other players, and just survive. This game (in theory) fits with my game style because I can be a lone wolf or social, depending on my mood. Today I saw headlines that there was a free weekend, so I thought that maybe some new content had been added, the game stabilized, and new fun stuff to explore. Unfortunately, I went to get on and was in a queue with 50+ players in front of me. Bounced out and found some low pop servers, which turned out to be based on the new DLC. So I paid $$ to play the game, but now to actually get on a server I've gotta pay up again? While waiting in the queue, I decided to review some of the latest discussions in the DayZ community. It was a rehash of messages from 5? 7? 10-years ago? Buggy, No Food, Insta-deaths, etc...I wish so bad for this game to be successful, but constant mis-steps have led me to write this review and I will uninstall the game. Tired of waiting for the game I want, so I will have to explore other options. Good Luck survivors, but if you can save your time and money, do not try this game.

DAYZ
The Good.
A truly difficult survival experience where you WILL die dozens of times to even learn the game.
Death is final - you don't keep anything from a previous life unless you happen to find your body. However, with no ability to pick where you spawn, good luck!

The Bad.
items are limited by count and that includes things in people inventories. There are only a few AR-15's on a server and chances are, someone else already has them.

The UGLY
This game supports mechanics that play into obscene behavior. You can be handcuffed, stripped of your clothes, items and shot to death. They get off on causing shame, and exercizing power over other people. This will most likely be by someone in full military gear with automatic weapons. Essentially the new players are at an extreme disadvantage and veteran players - especially if they have a crew - will always win. There is no chance at it being an even fight. Add into that the item count on things that could even the playing field - automatic weapons - and you're looking at 20 hours of play with no deaths to gear up to the level of someone fully geared up.  

Other players are the worst part of the game.
