DayZ: A Survival Thriller That Will Test Your Limits

DayZ is a hardcore survival simulation game set in a post-apocalyptic world overrun by zombies. Players must scavenge for supplies, avoid dangerous encounters, and build shelter in order to survive. The game is known for its unforgiving gameplay, realistic graphics, and immersive atmosphere. 


Intense Survival Experience

DayZ is a game that will test your limits. The world is vast and dangerous, and there are few places where you can truly feel safe. You will need to be constantly on your guard, as there are always threats lurking around every corner. From zombies to other players, there is always something out there that wants to kill you.

Realistic Graphics and Immersive Atmosphere

DayZ is a visually stunning game, with realistic graphics that bring the post-apocalyptic world to life. The game's atmosphere is also incredibly immersive, with sounds of the infected and the wind howling through the trees. This creates a truly tense and suspenseful experience.

Variety of Gameplay

There is a lot to do in DayZ. You can scavenge for supplies, build shelter, and craft weapons. You can also team up with other players to form groups, or you can go it alone and try to survive on your own. There are many different ways to play DayZ, and the game offers a lot of replayability.

Pros:

Intense survival experience
Realistic graphics and immersive atmosphere
Variety of gameplay
Huge open world to explore
Deep character customization
Extensive crafting system
Cons:

Difficult and unforgiving gameplay
Can be very buggy
Lack of a clear objective
Steep learning curve
Verdict:

DayZ is a challenging and rewarding game that will appeal to fans of hardcore survival simulations. The game's unforgiving gameplay, realistic graphics, and immersive atmosphere create a truly immersive and suspenseful experience. If you're looking for a game that will test your limits and keep you coming back for more, then DayZ is definitely worth checking out.

[h3]“The universe is a dark forest. Every civilization is an armed hunter stalking through the trees like a ghost, gently pushing aside branches that block the path and trying to tread without sound. Even breathing is done with care. The hunter has to be careful, because everywhere in the forest are stealthy hunters like him. If he finds other life—another hunter, an angel or a demon, a delicate infant or a tottering old man, a fairy or a demigod—there’s only one thing he can do: open fire and eliminate them. In this forest, hell is other people. An eternal threat that any life that exposes its own existence will be swiftly wiped out. This is the picture of cosmic civilization. It’s the explanation for the Fermi Paradox.”[/h3]
― [i]Liu Cixin, The Dark Forest [/i](黑暗森林)

I Voted this thumbs Down But i really wanted to use both. Thumbs up for some and thumbs down for others . 

This game was made before the whole battle Royal janra got perfected. basically PUBG is essentially the same kind of game. you Drop into Map , you start looting , you gear up, you Survive  and you fight other player. the real difference is that in pubg you get to the action very quickly because you can gear up in under 10 mins. in DAYZ it takes hours of searching and gearing up to get to the point where that intense Adrenalin is achieved. So its a matter of preference really. i feel that games like PUBG and Hunt Showdown took the basic premise of games like this and created them so that you can get into the action much faster. I for one do not have the patience to search around for hours for peaces of cloth and and guns with no ammo and broken fishing poles. about 20 mins of searching empty houses is about all i can take before i have to jump back into PUBG or Hunt. or if I really want this kind of long game , im going with something like like SCum or maybe Subsistence for a real Survival experience.Because the only real Diferance between DAYZ and PUBG is that there is some crafting in DAYZ, but games like Subsistance or Scum are many others are going to be much much more up to date when it comes to deep crafting . Also since this game is very old its not nearly as well optimized as something new and the mechanics seem to be dated as well. i feel that the price of this should have lowered. 
But try it out , you can try it for 2 hours and then return it if its not for you. 
some people love the search and the fact that it takes longer im sure adds to the intensity of PVP fights.
My feeling is that if you have hours to burn then go for it. however if you have a job and other things in life and you want something that allows you to get into something for a hour or so and then jump off. Go with PUBG. same exact concept, it just gets you to the action much faster, but its almost identical with in game goals , looting , surviving , searching , Running and fighting. just not crafting , 
but like i said if you want crafting , their are far better options than DAYZ.
Its not a bad game. it is much loved by many people , but i just feel like there might be better choices depending on 
your gaming style and goals.

I think this game has finally lived up to its potential with the last few updates. 

Picked this back up back in the day (around 2013 I think?) and i feels like it's been living in the Mods shadow since then; now though, I think it may have finally surpassed it.

Performance first, the game runs silky smooth at a high FPS even in large cities, something I considered impossible for this engine even just a few years ago. Frame rate drops happen very rarely  but it's less than once an hour so I can forgive this given the engine's age. 
There are also a couple of weird glitches involved too, such as Zombies phasing through doors or walls - while this does temporarily ruin immersion it's again infrequent enough to be overlooked, and part of me kind of enjoys the jitterish randomness of the old ArmA engine (though this is likely the nostalgia talking)

Loot balance on official servers is spot on. It always feels worthwhile searching every house on the off chance there may be some good loot in there; most of the time you find nothing, but loot drops are just frequent enough to keep your interest and make it worthwhile to check that one lonely, abandoned house on the way out of town.

There are a many different ways to keep your survival stats in the green, some of which are ethically questionable such as feasting on the freshly killed corpses of your fellow survivors - with interesting after effects such as an incurable mystery cough, or manic crazed laughing. 
Food and medicine drops are surprisingly rare, leaving you to rely upon more classic methods of acquiring sustenance like hunting or farming. All well and good-  if you know how - but make sure you cook that chicken right or you'll be out of action with salmonella poisoning before the Z's have chance to even look at you.

Finally the gun play is very satisfying and surprisingly in depth with its inventory management. This isn't the type of game where you hit 'R' to reload after spending one round; you need to ensure your equipment is prepared and ready after every engagement.
Some may not like this, but for me manually loading every bullet into a magazine and checking for breaks or jams in your weapon before a fight adds a whole new level of immersion to the game which really bring the world to life. Taking care of your equipment and gear serves to make it all the more heartbreaking when death inevitably find you. 

And make no mistake, death it coming. Be it from a gang of rogue walkers bludgeoning your battered body, slow painful wasting away due to hunger or thirst, or some camping bastard with a Mosin on Sniper hill, death or the threat of death is constant and oppressive in DayZ.
Having the grim reaper just a few steps behind you for the entirety of your play though makes the little moments of relief so much more satisfying in ways you wouldn't imagine. 
For example, finding a can of beans in any other video game is something overlooked and forgotten about seconds afterwards; but in DayZ beans bring life, and every one must be cherished and enjoyed. 

In conclusion, there is a ton of fun to be had in DayZ for anyone who enjoys survival games and I would recommend it to everyone with even a passing interest in zombie fiction.

Having put over 2500 hours in both modding and playing the game I am updating my review. In the past year DayZ devs have done a great job of shoring up the current base game. The stability injected is excellent and well worth the time. As a modder, there is a ton you can do with the game but my original though stays. If you are solo PvP servers are a bit toxic. If you are a Roleplayer, you have a bit more leeway and there are quite a few places where you can spend a lot of time exploring content and story.

tl;dr; The players/community of the server you play with determines if this game is worth buying.

Longer version:
The game itself is practically an alpha build of a half finished game. Fairly buggy and no longer supported actively by the developers. There are widespread stability issues that keep servers from being able to run longer than 4 hours continuously so there are constant restarts; merely inconvenient of there is no queue. Mod support is there and the only thing keeping the game alive... Active independent modders are single handedly building additional functionality for this game while we all wait for something better to come along and replace this piece of garbage. I would personally recommend getting this game during a sale if you MUST have it and pass on it altogether unless you have specific people you want to play with. This is not a solo friendly game. 


The game is awful, the community is worth trying out. I cannot recommend the game itself but the people I play with make the game more fun than if I played alone.

Edit after 5311 hours modding....

I met what sounded like a 10 year old who said it was his first time ever playing DayZ. He reminded me of my own kids who are now grown up and off doing their own lives. My dad reflexes immediately kicked in.

"RN" as he said his name was, did not know the controls at all. I had to help him learn how to pick up items, equip them, even to feed him when he couldn't feed himself. He was a sweet kid and full of life and joy at playing this exciting game.

We ran together for a few hours, till late at night we came across a small fenced encampment in the woods. RN was sick and we were hoping to find some Tetracycline to cure his illness. He'd also nearly bled out numerous times from encounters with zombie, so he was weak, but I was confident we could bring him back if we could just find some medicine.

I am searching and I hear RN calling for help. He's fighting a zombie. I equip my shovel and position myself to strike the zombie, but at the last moment, RN steps in the way. Both the zombie and RN fall to the ground. I drop to my knees, hoping to revive RN, but it's too late. He's gone. I've failed.

I was ready for backstabbing and betrayals, but hadn't even considered that I'd have to face the fact that I had failed as a father.

10/10

I bought this game when it came out for barely anything. The only reason I'm leaving this review is because my friend asked me what it cost, and I said "oh twenty bucks" before coming to the store to double-check and confirm.

Well, I lied.

They haven't added anything significant aside from basebuilding - infact, they table things like bows years in the past with the intent to fix, yet they never are. They've patched the bare minimum of bugs, in some cases creating new ones,  and they've jacked the price to 60 CAD. 

The game is fun, sure - but it's carried by it's community and community servers, nothing provided to you on-install makes this game worth it's native price. Zombies are glitched to shit and have never been improved, combat is gross and unintuitive, lag is wild and animations + combat + ladders + audio + bases + you name it: are jank. Nothing is smooth, nothing is clean, everything is a fucking chore to play through. Nothing feels natural when playing DayZ. You are stiff as a fucking corpse the whole way through.

The only thing that's enjoyable about DayZ is player interaction: which you can easily find in other games. Is it an awful game? Nah. Is it a good game? Sure, and it's lead dev was a pioneer in the genre back when it was a free mod. Is it a great game? absolutely not. Has it been elevated beyond it's origins as a - I repeat - FREE mod, with innovations and fresh gameplay systems to justify it's release and sale as a standalone game with DLC?

Absolutely fucking not. And don't let them forget that this launched damn near a decade ago as "DayZ Standalone," implying this shambling, putrid corpse of a once-Copernican Megalith of can-do, indie innovation actually has the strength to stand on it's own two feet anymore - which is laughable, considering they never correctly adapted the skeletons of the gameplay, engine and UI modules from it's parent engine of ARMA II. 

DayZ sits in the middling-limbo many former modding studios languish in; which is mediocrity and niche enjoyment. There's nothing inherently wrong with this: but charging 60 dollars Canadian for a badly-adapted MOD that hasn't shown any signs of significant progression, player-retention or game-health upkeep in the DECADE it's been on steam is unacceptable. That release date of 2018 is actually horse crap. That's untrue. This game has existed in a near-identical state on steam, since early-access, for all of my adolescence and early adulthood. The ONLY shit that's changed is gimmicky garbage you'd never even see use for in your entire playthrough. 

Will climbing a ladder kill you sometimes? Yeah for sure. Have we fixed that over the last ten years? Nah. 

But we added the ability for grenades to explode if put into a furnace!!!! 



Do not buy this game. Do not line Dean Hall's pockets. Go buy Arma II: The original title that DayZ plundered - badly - all it's systems from. DayZ existed as a mod before going independent in plenty adequate circumstances. There is absolutely no reason you should be paying this price for a product that's actually less competent than the free mod it was derived from. 

60 bucks Canadian - what a fucking joke.

(So I just got this game in 2024) I played Arma II 'Operation Arrowhead' DayZ way back in the day, it was pretty much vanilla and it was fun, I was always skeptical to get this game because of hearing about how buggy it was.

Pros - The game is off of its own engine and feels good, Its a little weird for me because I started on the Arma II Engine but I got used to it relatively quick
       -The servers and community seem to be very active and the people are pretty nice for the most part
       -The standalone DayZ Chernarus map is a big improvement from the Arma 2 and Arma 3 Chernarus 2020 mod map due to the amount of buildings you can go inside of and the entirely new locations to go visit

*Applicable to some as a pro or con -- Game plays way better with at least one other person as a friend, Playing solo is definitely doable but the game can get lonely without a friend to play with.

Cons -Cars definitely still drive clunky to this day but they seem to have made them less buggy
         -Game could use an engine overhaul at some point in the near future
         -Graphics could use an overhaul at some point in the near future (Ties in with the last con) because it doesnt hold up compared to Arma III Chernarus 2020 mod picture quality
         -Zombies equally as cancerous to fight as they were on the Arma 2 DayZ mod

Overall I would rate this a solid 4.5/5 of a game to play because it does have its faults here and there and you can tell its dated but I would only assume the devs will create a new title in the coming years and or upgrade this game on this title without making a new title, whatever they do, I just hope they do keep this game up with the times -- Considering Arma IV is in the works... Good job Devs and definitely recommend this game.

DayZ - Where Zombie Survival Meets Unpredictable Shenanigans

Step into the gritty post-Soviet wasteland of Chernarus in DayZ, where life is a perpetual struggle for survival and every can of beans might be your last. This hardcore zombie survival game throws you into a vast, unpredictable world with no map markers, daily quests, or scoreboards. It's just you, Chernarus, and the infectious undead hordes craving a piece of you.

Quirky Chaos Awaits:
In DayZ, there are no hand-holding tutorials or easy mode. Just Chernarus – a playground for up to 60 players, each trying to survive in their quirky way. Will you make friends, engage in epic battles over tasty beans, build a base, or risk a dramatic betrayal? The beauty is in the chaos, and every encounter is a potential chapter in your bizarre tale of survival.

Beware the Unexpected:
Surviving isn't just about dodging zombies; you'll face threats from wildlife, elements, and even your own hunger and thirst. Evade packs of wolves, outsmart bears with questionable motives, and pray for shelter during a downpour. Master complex survival mechanics, or Chernarus will chew you up and spit you out faster than you can say "tasty beans."

Ready Your Gear, Fashionista:
Your style is your armor. Patch up those damaged clothes, craft improvised items, and strut into seemingly deserted cities for loot. Fix up a car, hide it in your secret base, and venture into contaminated zones (if you dare). Just remember, you're not getting far without a full hazard suit and a fashionable gas mask.

PvP Pandemonium:
In Chernarus, PvP isn't just a game, it's a lifestyle. Expect intense firefights in hotspots like military bases, where survivors are either after your loot, hunting for sport, or just terrified you'll shoot first. Learn to fight, know when to flee, and always watch your back – because one bullet can change everything, turning your quirky adventure into a respawn screen.

Customize the Chaos:
If vanilla isn't your flavor, head to the Steam Workshop. Join an active community of survivors and spice up your DayZ experience. Thousands of fan-made features, maps, and guns await, all easily managed from the game launcher. Install mods, shape the mayhem to your liking, and revel in the delightful unpredictability of DayZ.

In DayZ, survival isn't just about staying alive; it's about embracing the unpredictable, crafting your story, and savoring the quirky chaos of Chernarus. So, pack your beans, sharpen your wits, and dive into a world where each quirky encounter might be your last - or your weirdest.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

Many reviewers talk about all the potential...  You pay for potential when you buy a game in early access.  If you buy this game in it's current state, as a released title, you are getting robbed.  Steam should pull it down and refuse to sell any more copies.

NOTHING WORKS
Not the crafting system, the survival system, the medical system, melee combat, the cars, inventory, NOTHING WORKS.

The only thing this game can promise you is diasppointment and frustration.


UPDATED 12/18/2020

This is the first time I have played DayZ in years.  Within the first  15 minutes I've experienced two bugs.  One which allowed me to craft rags from the same pair of pants three times, and then wear the pants with no change to their condition.  The other which which now prevents me from accessing my inventory (with a different character on a different server) or pick up items.  These bugs were both in OFFICIAL SERVERS with no mods.

Nothing has changed.  This game is still the biggest steaming load of dung ever made.

The devs should be ashamed that they ever participated in such a rotten display if incompetence.

You are a fool if you spend a cent on this game.



Fast Forward to January 2024

I rented my own GTX server which I have been running for about a month.  There are a bunch of mods that help make this mess of a game playable.

I decided to give an official server a try tonight.
Error 0x001001 Can not connect.

Verified my game files, manually unloaded all mods, restarted my computer, restarted steam, re-verified game files.  I have tried to join 10 different Official servers.  Same error.

Crappiest game ever.  The Devs should not be allowed to work in the industry ever again.  What a sloppy, embarrassing mess.

Amazingly enjoyable even in single player PVE!!!

I'm not here for what most people are here for, I mostly enjoy single player, though I could enjoy a bit of grouping up and adventuring but I suck so bad at PVP I think even my parents would be ashamed of me, and they hardly even know what computers are. It's an age thing I guess, don't have the reflexes anymore.

So I decided do dig in when it was on sale and check what this old workhorse was up to. I had tried it before at the early stages of when the mod was created, and even though it seemed kind of interesting I didn't really get the concept back then, also, so much must have changed since its humble beginnings!

I set up a LAN server and went into it with a little worry as I know this is pretty hardcore, plus I had no real idea that there was any crafting implemented so WOW what a surprise!! I quickly realized that this is as close as you can come to 1st person Project Zomboid. Certainly not even half of PZ's mechanics are in DayZ, but those that are in there feel very much like it. So if you've been waiting for a PZ first person variant, seems it has been around for a very long time already, you just haven't really tried this, I guess...

I've played about 7000 h of 7 Days To Die so zombies don't really freak me out anymore, but they definitely can give you plenty of tense moments when you're all alone and without much gear - I guess that's what all of you regulars experience on a daily basis, however I really made that experience last, also I'm dependent on it as I can't loot other players for the gear I want, and I enjoy it a lot! If I had been on a PVP server I would have probably died a thousand deaths as the playstyle I adapted really only works if you are in control, without other players around. But even though me being alone, it works, and it works great!

I'm having a ton of fun, especially since I love the Cherna map since I've played Arma 2 and I've long wanted to see it again and explore, and I'm getting that and more compared to how it was in Arma 2. And even though I'm alone I'm having lots of tense moments in the game, I still need to be careful, and need to make every shot count.

The only thing I've done differenty from the original game is that I've installed an admin mod with which I can toggle god mode, which I will use to fend off wolf packs, which will eventually happen. Those are really meant to make groups of coop-players stick together in the more difficult areas. They are however a 100% death sentence for a lone player without much experience and I've seen that there are a lot of areas with wolves on the map and I find that a tad unreasonable for my personal game. I don't like it if can't by any chance really avoid dying under such circumstances, and I get more out of being able to move freely than having to avoid all the forests farther inland just to play the game as it's meant to be. I don't do that anyway, I play PVE, so I'm already off script. I play to have fun and mindlessly dying isn't part of it. I want a challenge, but a challenge with a chance, not just a random event I can't control and which means certain death. <- No fun! Anyway, fixed that problem and now I'm enjoying it!

Anyway, fantastic game, I can absolutely recommend this even to people who shy away from it for PVP reasons, it's still a fantastically fun experience even on your own, with tons to do, to craft, base build, loot, and despite its age, it still looks very nice and the map is a blast! The loot scarceness was bothering me a bit in the beginning, but the game pretty much only contains items you can actually use, so no fluff that will scrap up your inventory, and to be honest, I still can't keep up with my crate building and storage barrell collecting. The loot is still pretty nuts once you actually get into playing for real! 

I'd say go for it if you enjoy zombie survival, because it fits that bill 100% as well as being a very popular PVP game (for good reason!).

And on a personal note, I would actually love to enter PVP servers and just play a travelling medic, carrying food and water and med supplies to trade with all players that are in a pinch or just want to have a chin wag, but firstly everybody would have to konw there is a friendly medic on the lose on the server, and secondly I'd probably get abused and shot a lot ;D. No respect in this world anymore ;)

◕︎ ‿︎ ◕︎  DayZ is a game with mixed feelings and mechanics. It’s not bad, but it’s not good either. Unlike Rust, The Long Dark, or GreenHell.. There’s no way to explain this game to a new player. A new player might return the game and get their money back or keep the game and give it a try. Why? The game isn’t really basic, and there’s no tutorial or explanation on how it works. YouTube is a good source for a tutorial. Don’t buy this game for good zombie mechanics; the zombies will slow you down big time. I love DayZ, no question about that. I’ve played the game since the beginning of Alpha Standalone and also played DayZ Mod Arma2. To make the game work, you should play with friends or others on Discord. Servers make the game better with mods! Do you want to be a robber or a hero? Well, don’t wait any longer. DayZ modded servers are here for you! The game allows some practice, and it will take some time for you to figure it all out. But when you know how to survive well, you will feel like a god in this awesome survival game.

Pros: 
 ☑︎ Survival 
 ☑︎ Hard 
 ☑︎ Good Servers
 ☑︎Fun
---------------------------------
Cons:
☒︎Zombies *cough* they act more like paranoid humans with a sniffy nose like a dog
☒︎Sick why? 
☒︎Not many options to build a base
☒︎The game is sometimes quite boring, and you’re losing interest
☒︎Want to feel like a god early in the game? Solution: a knife!
----------------------------------
❤︎ I would give this game is 7 out of 10. It’s good, but not truly special in any way like other survival games.

A glorified walking simulator that was made by an incompetent, greedy team of lazy developers.

Don't be deceived by those scripted YouTube videos where everyone is geared to the brim with guns, gun attachments, vehicles, armor, and such. Where factions lead wars between each other, that just isn't the case. In actual DayZ, you will rarely ever encounter a player, and in most cases, you will die out of either hunger or thirst. If you want what you see on YouTube, go play modded servers.

The fact that out of 5.8 million players, only 17.3% have actually eaten and drank anything, while only 14% have equipped a weapon says more than enough.

And don't even get me started on the bugs (such as where a zombie can apparently survive 15 shots straight to the chest and an additional 10-ish hits).

Overall, it is not worth the price at all. DayZ dick riders can keep crying about it all they want; it ain't changing the facts. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

It's a harsh, gritty, survival game that not all will welcome. There's a high learning curve, not suited to being invested in your character or your gear. You will die. But that's part of the challenge and the fun.  No two encounters are exactly alike, and strange things can and will happen.  There's levels of schadenfreude and nostalgia to this game where overcoming obstacles and experiencing loss go hand in hand. Encounter new foes, make friends, lose it all, and start again. The greater challenge, is you, will you stay calm and adapt to survive, or give in to harsh circumstances? The choice is yours.

I've had this game since 2014; literally a decade at this point. (The store page will say it released in 2018 but that was just when it left early access).

In that decade it has gone from pretty much unplayable to barely playable, and that is the singular significant milestone they've hit. The original Arma II mod is still quite literally the better version. The fact the devs had the gall to ask the playerbase to recommend this game for the Labor of Love award is beyond me.

Kind of amazing how this game is a decade old and the mod is still better. Even more amazing is the best version of Dayz I've ever played was a Roblox clone. No I'm not joking, Apocalypse Rising on Roblox is better than this game in every way except graphics. Just go play that. It's free.

The UI of this game is awful. Like, the amount of time you waste just fucking around with inventory management is like 1/3 of your play time.

Everything is needlessly clunky. Want to load bullets in a magazine? Do you drag and drop the bullets into it? NO. You equip your gun. Drag and drop the magazine out of the gun. Equip the magazine. Drag and drop the bullets into the magazine while you have it equipped. Then you hold the mouse button to load bullets one at a time. Needlessly complicated, clunky, and annoying.

The combat sucks. Floaty movement, stupid health system, and stupid stuff like how you have to manually press R every single time you shoot a pump or bolt action gun to pump it or rack the bolt. Your character doesn't do that automatically like every other shooter ever made. Why would I not want to pump my shotgun after I shoot it?

Loot is spread too thin. I looted the entirety of Cherno, the biggest city in the map, on an empty server. I found like three guns that all had no magazines or ammo, a bunch of damaged clothes, some duct tape, and two cans of peaches I couldn't eat because I never found a can opener. Compare this to the mod where I can loot one building and find two M16s with multiple magazines in the same city. The loot pool is too spread out and there's too much filler bullshit in the loot. Why are there so many clothes?

Don't buy this, it's trash.

I just got this game and played for an hour on a low-population official server to learn the controls and stuff, then hopped onto Spaggie's vanilla server, and decided to loot small towns and slowly make my way to a city. I couldn't find anything valuable nor anything to protect myself against others but a baseball bat.

Two "friendly" people stopped me and told me that I could trust them. I didn't trust them, but I also had nothing to fight back, and they were right next to me anyway. So, I played along, and that friendship ended just how you would assume.

After that, I respawned with a new character, ignored everything, and rushed to a city this time. I managed to get my hands on a Derringer and an MK II, and I had a knife to fight off the zombies. Now that I was loaded, I needed some food and better clothes. I found some chips and started eating them on the second floor of a house, watching the sunset... until I heard his footsteps. I slowly sneaked behind him, missed my first shot, and he started begging for his life in voice chat. His last words before I cold-heartedly murdered him were "I am your friend." His body was LOADED with ammo, meds, and food.

I literally didn't experience that dopamine rush I had when looting that poor guy's body in any game for a really, really long time. Everything in this game is intense af, and feeling vulnerable at all times makes even the simplest walks fun. I have never felt more alive playing any game for years.

I've spent almost 20 hours running around, trying to collect stuff only to die to random crap.

This game's not hard because it's hard to play, but because it's obscure and has a shady design. You can't collect rocks unless you look for them near tracks despite being in a massive field. Most trees don't bear fruit. Everything breaks after using it a few times, unless you're lucky enough to find something in good condition. Items sometimes don't work. Controls sometimes don't work. And the worst offender, I have to google every single piece of information, such as making fire or how to find food in the wild.

Pretty sure some people will enjoy just walking out and figuring everything out from trial and error, but not me.
you spawn get stuff then die then repeat

I wish this game was good, I love the premise. Typical play through... wander for about 30 minutes, trying to find at least some food (though I did find a few pairs of sunglasses and other crap), aggro a zombie or two and get taken down to half health. Struggle to find any food or water, certainly not enough to regain any health given how long it takes and how far you have to walk. Find a few random junk melee items. By the time I encounter a 3rd zombie I'm already down to 25% health from starvation and lack of water. 3rd Zombie kills me. Don't waste your time playing this game. Any imagery of a geared up player is pure fantasy, 1 in 10,000 chance at best.

I've clocked over 1,600 hours on DayZ now so I feel it's time to update my review. DayZ is by far my favourite survival game and that's down the the ambience and the play style the community have adopted.

In order to get the best experience from DayZ you'll need to find the server that's right for you. Nobody should be playing on official servers because they aren't policed by admin so you have zero comeback against cheaters.

My friends and I have had fun building bases but after watching streamers like Smoke, I understand that isn't how DayZ plays best. If there were more no-base servers in Asia, I'd play them exclusively. Base builders spend too much of their time in their bases admiring their loot so even of a healthy population server you will have fewer encounters with other players. I prefer to roam the map now. Playing solo and meeting random people is where the most fun is to be had. However, not all servers will have players open to teaming up with randoms. You're best playing on DayOne style servers if you want that experience. These uneasy alliances between strangers can lead to experiences that you're unlikely to find outside of DayZ. Some of the community generated maps/mods, such as Namalsk enhance the PVE elements of the game and force survivors to work cooperatively to overcome the elements.

The base game is in great shape now. You should avoid heavily modded servers because the guns they inevitably add dilute the loot tables making it take longer to combine gun, magazine and ammo to become 'geared'. The one thing like like to see implemented is see more options for crafting with tanned leather such as canteens. The only thing tanned leather can currently be used for is backpacks and shelters.

The addition of permanent gas zones on Chernarus and the bunker on Livonia have provided some fantastic end game goals but there's plenty of fun to be had roaming aimlessly and just surviving.

This article is filled with lots of expletives. No, I will not remove or censor them. Bohemia Interactive has earned them well in exchange for my money and time spent on this game.

Buy this game if you hate yourself - like if you seriously fucking hate yourself. Sink 67 hours into it having to put up with continual bullshit of losing your semi-decent gear that you spent 4 hours a life seeking but being able to actually use in a pvp such as dying from the following:

Random illnesses for no good cause.
Becoming ill from drinking a bit too much clean water even drawn from moving water.
Overcoming the illness but still dying from the resultant stat debuff.
Being hit by a zombie carrying a disease picked up from another player.
Committing suicide for every time you get an illness because you don't have a degree in DayZ medicine nor an entire infirmary to hand because you're out in the sticks with nothing but a rag to wipe your arse with.
Get blown up by a grenade you pulled the pin on because there are next to no prompts or tutorials on how to actually throw a blasted grenade at a horde of zombies at the bottom of a watchtower you climbed up to escape them.
Or get battered by somebody at the spawn with a gardening hoe despite yourself having a hatchet to cut them up with.

Perhaps instead you put yourself through the total agony of attempting to build a base in order to lessen your losses per life. However due to not having pliers or wire, be unable to build a simple gate to lock your stash up - get raided and cleared out every time despite your efforts at concealment and use of lock pins to secure the premises in the short term by the time you return to it after getting some sleep IRL.

Call it "skill issue" all you want. If you fucking hate yourself, your life, and want to be utterly crushed in your soul by some poxy pixels on a screen (that is before coming across total dickwad players); this is the game for you! 

I have given too much time to this game already, learning a bunch of things on YouTube between sessions. Even as a presently unemployed fellow, this game is far too in-depth to be genuinely enjoyed. Learning to play and then getting buttfucked over repeatedly by this game is not a mere occupation in of itself by which some streamers make their money compiling the highlights of their runs - it is self-imposed auto-sodomy with a spiked mace laced with AIDs. You go from "Gah, what bullshit?!" between each death to "Don't be a little bitch, just try again, it has to get better" and within a space of four more hours to you are up to "Man, now that was absolute fucking nonsense!" repeatedly. 

Never mind my money, I want the time back from the learning and suffering this game has demanded. It demands too much and pisses into your face in return.

Its 2am, you've been up most of the night searching for a pickaxe, which is essential for collecting stones used in building your flag pole. You make it back to your stash only to find its missing. Someone found it while you were away. You've lost all your building materials, but luckily on the way home you found a tent. You set it up, hidden deep within the woods NW of Myshkino. A road less traveled. You log out for the night taking only what your inventory slots allow. 

The next day rolls around and work was exhausting. You wanna hop on and play some DayZ. You finally get logged in and you're standing in the forest. Huh, that's weird, you thought you logged off in the tent. You look down and see the remains of a tent. Some one broke into it with a knife. All is lost a second time. You are now distraught over losing so much progress. Its a 15 minute run back to NWAF to loot. You've decided to give up, but then you hear it. A crack of a single shot to the East. You hurriedly make a stash in a pine tree nearby and rush off. Thinking what are the chances this man stole my loot. You make it near Vybor. You notice a large base built in the construction building. It is a clan base. You know this clan from dodging them in NWAF and Tisy. You decide its best to avoid the area, but instead there is another crack of a shot. Then black. You've been knocked out. You wait praying you get up hoping that you don't see that feared death screen. Finally the light of day peers through the darkness and you see... 4 players standing around you. You can't access your inventory. You are unable to equip any weapons. It was bait shots, your hands are bound and you are at the mercy of the clan. They start speaking, but they are Russian, you don't speak any language but English. One speaks broken English asks you questions about dogs. "Huh?" You're confused on why they are asking you about dogs. NO, they are calling you a dog. "WHAT?" They get more and more aggressive. Eventually the kitted out one points is VSD at you. Says "Goodbye Dog." 

You are at the "You are Dead" screen, thinking about what just happened. You're upset, you lost all those hours of work to an unfortunate series of events. You are sitting in silence when it hits you. You are not going to let it end that way. You click "Respawn". Determined to get revenge on the clan, you set out from your randomized spawn near the coast. You run across some railroad tracks and hear another CRACK. "You are Dead" is back. Freshie killers sent you back to that dismal screen. You give up for the night. you just can't handle anymore. You'll pick it back up tomorrow you say.
The best worst time you'll every have. You'll make friends, lose friends and ruin all your IRL relationships all in one package. 10/10 would recommend.

I really want to enjoy this game, but my experience on PC has been the worst. I had fun playing this game on Xbox game pass for a good amount of time. And now when I actually buy it on PC when it's on sale, it's garbage. It took me about an hour to actually get in to a server, and within that time I never actually could find the server I was looking for. The server menu is confusing, slow, buggy, and unresponsive. When I did actually get in to the game, It couldn't run at all. It ran at a smooth 60 fps, but it froze so fucking much it was unplayable. The controls are a little wonky, and the gameplay becomes a slide show at the literal worst moments. Every time a zombie ran up to me, my game would completely freeze with no sound for about 5 seconds before unfreezing and then freezing again a second later. It took me around 5 minutes to actually start playing when I got in because the game would freeze over and over while I was just standing still. I don't get it. This game can't run for shit and I feel stupid for even wasting my money on it. I want to like this game, but it's unplayable. I do not recommend. I'm sure it's fun when things actually work though.

Freshie perspective:

This game is fastly becoming one of the greatest games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. 
The atmosphere is unforgiving, not in an immediate way but in a kind of looming doom.  
You lose all your hard earned loot when you die which kind of develops a Taoist mindset where your intention is to live well and not let materialism be a distraction from the true way.
The mundane is intense and puts me in a primal state of being of which my biology has been accustomed to for thousands of years. 
It is only in this particular iteration of my being am I completely unplugged from my natural state due to the advancement of tech and the rapid industrialization of man, yet Day Z really soothes my savage soul by allowing me to use the very survival core that's allowed my ancestors to survive. 

I never had use of knowing specifically where the sun rose or set irl, nor did I care for the position of the stars, nor did I bother learning how to move stealthily as none of these vastly useful things that have been key to survival were ever useful in my urbanized hi-tech life. Thanks to this game I feel more in tune with the world and how poetic everything truly is. 

The apocalypse is such a freeing concept which is probably why I've gravitated toward literature and media regarding the topic, yet to be actually in it through Day Z is another level for me. 

When I'm in the game, my senses are on high alert: my eyes scan the horizon for movement, my ears steady listening for any aberrations, my blood coursing through my being as if to ready my sinews for fast twitch movement. Not to mention the "extrasensory perception" that kick starts somehow and allows me to know where danger is coming from.
It's a real trip and pleasure to be in this momentous feeling of self reliance. 
My brain and body cannot tell if this is just a game. There's some weird kind elation when looting and in the same breath a kind of strange fondness for the things I loot. "MINE" says my brain, and my body facilitates the necessary senses for me to keep what is "mine."

I'm a fairly new player yet I feel I've experienced the most intense moments playing this game than I have in any other game I've sunk thousands of hours into. 
I've met some proper characters who's names and deeds my brain bothered remembering; which made me realize that I'm not bad with names, it's just that there's no need to really remember names in my modern life. 
I met Will who was a veteran of the game that just waited by the coast in his little house and farm, who's sole purpose was to teach Freshies the game, I met Corey who snuck up on me but did not kill me and instead let me come with him to his hidden base in the forest by a military encampment, I met Carl who was already doomed from a late stage sickness when I found him, who in his last moments of life had me witness him jump off from a high building where he unfortunately lived and broke both his legs and all I could do was put him down with a rusty shovel as he thanked me for releasing his spirit. 

This is not a game for the feint of heart to be sure, in fact this is a game for the stout of heart who wish to test their mettle against the forces of the self, nature, man, and the undead.

Immersive, challenging, open world sandbox.  Not for those who get attached to their gear or avatar due to the likelihood of frequent death.  You probably won't respawn anywhere near where you died, so getting your carried inventory back is difficult. Official servers tend to be overrun with hackers and griefers, so the community run servers are your best bet to start on.  Just be discriminating and maybe do some research before joining those, as owners/admins can be corrupt or self-serving. Many games have this issue, it's not unique to DayZ. I recommend this game to those who have longer blocks of time to play (couple of hours minimum), as just popping in and out is more liable to get your toon killed and keep your progress slow.  Expect weird bugs and game mechanics, some amusing and some frustrating. Use vehicles with caution. Keep it simple to start out. Bring friends and an abundance of rags. Don't take things too seriously, just have some fun.

Having played this game for more than 150 hours, I can say that this game is definitely the best in its genre (despite the bugs that it has) 
This game is quite realistic, which is what I was hooked on. In it, you can build a base, you can get sick and have to look for pills, kill zombies, cook, craft, fix things/weapons, do gardening, collect a car.
The game can be played alone or with friends. One can get bored, but you can meet a lot of interesting people. This game will give you a lot of different emotions: both positive and negative.
I recommend the game to those who are really a fan of realistic games and who want to try themselves as a strategist in the war for loot.

DayZ True Review......
Dayz has been on the market for years, but the devs act like its new and exciting every release, which is a good thing they care and keep adding very cool stuff to the game different quality of life items different weather how the zeds act the toxic zones you need full body gear to go into, the newest vehicle the humvee, the weather like storms and rain, i have 1 little tiny issue which doesnt effect how awesome this game is, the DMR ( Designated Marksmen Rifle) why would the devs only limit it to an acog scope why not a hunting scope it is a sniper rifle not a battle rifle im hoping they correct that.. I would highly recommend buying this game for sure really is the only game on steam i can honestly say is only getting better, but what would top it off is if they put helicopters in the vanilla version instead of leaving it to mods, which is not a big deal but for those of us that like to play vanilla version no mods a helicopter spawn would be sweet and lets us have fun while staying vanilla. Great thing about this game is the community servers where owners and admins ban cheaters which if you play official servers where cheaters and hackers are they consume official servers so dont waste your time in those i secretly believe the devs leave it like that so they can shut down the official servers other wise they would allow admins to start cleaning them up. Community servers are your top choices if your new to the Dayz community there you can get to know the game in servers that have only Player verse environment, or you like to kill join a server strictly pvp or join a server with PVP and PVE zones there are so many servers out there try them out add to favorites the ones you like if your a noob i suggest Fairplay by hydro to start out i have many hours on dayz now owned it from when it was a bug filled game, i can promise you they have and are still fixing any bugs reported to them and at the current state the game is now you wont have too many issues with bugs the most common is lag which is mostly the server you play on if its located too far from where you live, I paid for this game i rate this game a Solid 10/10 as it is now and as it improves aor adds more threw the years it is exactly how it appears great fun especially with a group of squad mates or solo its all up to you, be a friendly character or be a evil one its your choice and you can change threw the game by just not killing someone or just by killing a rando, THIS GAME IS BY FAR THE BEST GAME OUT THERE its got base building survival, crafting, looting driving shooting hiding everything the players wanted way above its time SO YES !!!!!! SAFE TO BUY THIS GAME YOU WILL LOVE IT

After a few hours of playing and a couple of hours of guide videos, I learned how to pass the early game stage, avoid illness and manage thirst and hunger, and really enjoy the game's atmosphere. And the atmosphere is really what makes it so much fun for me. The interaction with other players too, but since I'm one of those mostly silent ones (I have a microphone, but choose not to use it, for personal reasons :p), it's mostly the atmosphere.

Whether it's just sitting in front of the fire, waiting for the chicken breast to cook or clothes to dry, or sitting in an attic of a house, waiting for the rain to pass while checking the equipment and reading the descriptions (I'm new, remember), or waiting to see where that player you (think you) saw will be going.

I can't see myself playing this one competitively, for hundreds of hours, but even as a casual, I really am enjoying it and can really recommend it even to am players that don't have that much time on their hands.

As a DayZ enthusiast, my recent gameplay tallying 97 hours of my 222 total hours spent attests to the game's gripping survival-driven narrative, especially in the company of friends. Over time, the game has undergone substantial evolution, evident in its recent iterations showcasing remarkable enhancements.

DayZ maintains its essence in a world where survival is unforgiving, presenting relentless challenges that push players to their limits. Scavenging for resources remains an intense pursuit, with towns often yielding scarce supplies, underscoring the game's harsh reality.

The game's atmospheric setting, Chernarus, continues to emanate an eerie allure within its barren landscapes and rural enclaves. Its immersive world, replete with intricate details and historical context, forms a captivating milieu for player exploration.

While navigating this realm, moments range from exhilarating encounters to tranquil isolation, defining the gameplay experience. Interactions with fellow survivors are where the game truly shines, offering potential narratives of cooperation, caution, or betrayal—a hallmark of DayZ.

However, the undead inhabitants of this post-apocalyptic world, while pivotal, lack the depth to significantly elevate gameplay. Their behavior and combat mechanics still fall short, failing to pose a substantial challenge compared to the complexities of human interactions.

DayZ's gameplay alternates between gripping excitement and serene exploration. Yet, these fleeting instances of tension and drama, spurred by player interactions, constitute the game's most captivating facet. It demands perseverance and rewards players with unique tales, despite occasional bugs and inconsistencies within its improved framework.

Overall, DayZ remains an immersive survival journey that has come a long way. Its capacity to immerse players in a social survival experience within a vivid world is commendable. Nevertheless, those expecting flawless gameplay might encounter sporadic imperfections.

For those intrigued by a challenging survival narrative steeped in atmosphere and social dynamics, DayZ stands as a testament to the genre's potential, offering an engaging and ever-evolving journey.

Controls are janky as hell. The melee combat (which is all a new player has) absolutely sucks. Sometimes you'll swing, sometimes you won't which leaves you standing there getting your face pushed in by the first thing you come across be it zombie or player. I've seen plenty of videos of people exploiting broken mechanics of the game. And giving new players the "its hard, get good" doesn't apply here cause the game just doesn't work. The few times I found melee weapons they weren't any more effective than the random stick I got from a bush. A bush mind you that caused my character to start bleeding. And since this is another game that treats every human player like they don't have an immune system is basically a death sentence. 
I give props to the players that put up with the broken game but claiming those broken mechanics make the game challenging does not make the game good. I've tried to play multiple times and I have never survived passed the first fruit and bandage the game starts you with. Again, if the game were just challenging fine, but when no house within an entire village has a scrape of food (In the starter area btw) then that's not challenging, its just a bad game.

This game is a must have for any HARDCORE gamer!!!! If you like getting chased by Zombies that are realistic fast trying to eat you and kill you. Players that are both friendly hello's, or a quick fight to the death. Usually by melee combat, or a shootout can also be a mix of both. Oh I also need to mention that when you DIE, and you will a lot, especially in the beginning of your ventures. You drop everything you have, EVERYTHING!!!!!! Its all at risk every time you play and if you stash your gear, Its at risk of someone maybe finding it and ripping you off, or even ripping you off and trapping around where your stash was. You can Die by Starvation, Thirsting, Freezing, Burning, Vast different Diseases, Bleeding out, Falling, Shot, Maimed, Murdered (many ways), and even Eaten, and not by just Zombies you have Cannibal Players as well. There isn't a way to describe the feelings DayZ gives you because at some point you will feel them all. Always getting new content and improved by Dev Team, tons of mods. Massive Maps and content. Best, and, "Most Realistic Survival Game" you can play in my opinion. 642 hours and still playing. 5 stars. Money Well Spent. This game is unnecessarily complicated. Nothing is self-evident. You cant find out what things do easily, you have to spend hours going to video game college and reading reddit threads and Steam guides and watching YT videos just to be able to do basic things like make a fishing pole or make bandages. 

I have spent nearly 5 hours not finding a single player in-game playing on 40-60 pop official servers, havent found a single gun, have only found one piece of food ever, and am basically just done trying to give this game a try.

Theres no reason why the game itself cant explain things as you click on them and get some basic information like Rust and other games do. 

I honestly have no idea how people find this fun. I love hardcore survival games, I have 12k hours in Rust and a few thousand in other similar games, but this just isnt worth learning in my opinion. Im sure I could spend a few days full-time reading information and memorizing a bunch of tasks to complete to be able to do simple things, but its a video game and I came here to have fun and havent a single moment of fun.

My experience so far has been...
1. Spawn in and die 40 minutes later because I couldn't find food/water quick enough\
2. Spawn in, get lucky with some weapons and food, die to someone camping behind a door
3. Spawn in, die instantly to zombies
4. Spawn in, die instantly to a player
5. Spawn in, get the jump on a player, get killed by another player while looting
6. Spawn in, travel to a nearby military camp, get gassed while looting the military camp
7. Spawn in, get lucky with loot, get shot at, run for dear life, black out due to blood loss shortly after, and than die

After 5 hours, that has been my experience so far. Is it fun? I don't know. Am I happy when i'm playing? I don't know. Am I sad while i'm playing? I don't know. Will I continue playing? Yeah... Why? I don't know. Maybe the true beauty of the game isn't about getting looted up the wazzoo and surviving like a true champ, but rather the struggle, the journey, the tears that you shed along the way that write a story as you spend countless hours begging the gods up above for a single piece of chocolate to get you from one city to another in hopes of finding some food or water. You cross many dangers, and encounter many many many near death experiences. When you do finally get a house that blesses you with not only food, but a backpack, ohhhh buddd... You can suddenly do anything... The world is in YOUR hands... YOU are the main character now, all that beautiful time spent that you can never get back has finally payed off. Things are finally taking a turn for the better, this is the lord himself... blessing you with your daily bread. Nobody can stop you........   *BANG* *BANG* "You are dead" Maybe DayZ represents something more than just an open world zombie survival game... Maybe DayZ represents our lives on a much deeper, much more meaningful level. We constantly strive to beat life, we want to be rich, we want to be "OP". It is because of this blinding mindset, we loose sight of the beauty that is around us everyday. We have a massive world to explore, with countless stories to tell and countless stories to write, yet we choose to only focus on the loot, to only focus on getting the best cars, the best houses, the best guns... DayZ is not a game... it is.... a life style

**UPDATE 2023**

It's way better now. It's a lot more fun, a lot of the issues I had have been fixed. The game runs fantastically for me, the animations and movement are nice and smooth, and the amount of mods and community servers available keep the game nice and healthy. Failing that, there're always ways to play it alone if you're the antisocial type but it does detract from the experience.

There're plenty of toxic people in it, but it's a multiplayer game with a large PVP element so that's to be expected. To balance it, there're just as many if not more people willing to talk, mess around, team up, or are just generally friendly and won't fight you if you don't fight them, so it keeps things nice and interesting.

**UPDATE 2016**

[b]tl;dr DO NOT BUY THIS GAME[/b]

Previously this game ran pretty well, for what it was. I could maintain a relatively stable framerate consistently which kept me pretty happy. Despite the previous lack of loot and features to actually use, the game was fun. However, since the more recent updates over the past few months, the game has gone to utter shit. My framerate has dipped so ridiculously low that it's literally impossible to play the game. I get barely 30fps in fields and roads, and it dips to 10 or less in towns. 

Honestly, that's unacceptable. Especially when I can launch Arma 2 and get 60+ fps almost all the time. I have a friend who has very high end gear and he gets terrible framerates too, so it isn't an isolated issue. The more recent update that claims to improve FPS (0.59) didn't improve my FPS at all. Update 0.60 claims to increase FPS even further but I have my doubts.

This has been in early access for too long, games which were put into early access around the same time and after have since been released, and I would honestly suggest you go and play one of those instead. If you want a survival game, go check out Escape From Tarkov - it's a good looking game and it probably won't suffer the same horrific performance issues as DayZ.

I'm sorry to say that this game has gone from something relatively decent to utter trash. Avoid it like the plague.


**ORIGINAL REVIEW**


A man took my trousers off and force fed me rotten bananas

But asides from that, I've had a good time. I was skeptical after having an awful time on the mod, what with the abundance of KoS and just a generally unfriendly atmosphere. I was also one of the veteran Arma players who gave it a go, so my knowledge of Arma's mechanics paid off when I decided I wanted to turn the tables. I got bored of doing that after a few hours or so anyway.

The standalone - I have to say - is a thousand times better than the mod, the community so far has been wonderful. Even the aforementioned bandit and other encounters were actually really polite (I'm not saying I'll take my pants off for you if you say please, I'm not a slut :c). I've been helped out by fellow survivors as a new spawn, and in return I helped out other new spawns, as well as the people who helped me if I came across them later on. 

The game is hard, even on the regular servers. If you come across even a single zombie when you're unarmed it's best to just run as far as you can and hope it loses interest. If you start bleeding, you're gunna have to sacrifice your shirt to bandage yourself. You'll need to make more decisions as to what you want to carry around with you, inventory management is much more important now. You also have to be ready to lose that gear if you come across a bandit or two who have the advantage. 

Naturally, there are lots of bugs, some of which are incredibly irritating, but when you pay for an early access game you have to expect that, so you can't complain about it. It's annoying when you lose your character, or when loot never spawns, or when zombies walk through walls, but they'll get fixed.

So overall, I can't complain. Whilst the game is in this state, I can't tell you what is bad and what isn't, only the very core mechanics have been implemented and even then they aren't fully completed yet, my advice would be to wait. £20 (or however much it is in your region) is a lot of money to spend on an early access game, especially if you're unsure about it. As the days go by, Bohemia will be adding in vehicles, more loot, zombies that abide by the laws of physics and so on. It's best to wait the game has more depth before you make a final decision.

I'm glad I bought it though, it's a damn good game and the developers deserve my money. I also met Dean Hall at Rezzed last year, he's a lovely guy and works really hard on his projects, if any indie developer deserves your money, it's him.

*Update 12/23/2023*
You know, after 5 years from my last update and over 8 years since my original review, I'm happy to say this is actually a pretty decent survival game. Some of the mechanics haven't aged well, loot can sometimes still be annoyingly sparse, and zombies are tough to deal with without firearms, but this is a solid, full-featured game now. I definitely place this more in the "hardcore" survival genre, but only in that it has brutal survival mechanics and unforgiving RNG when looting sometimes. 

This game is definitely not for me still, but if you like the hardcore survival & permadeath genre then this is one you could really lose some time to. I'd recommend or for anyone looking for that experience, even if it hasn't necessarily aged well after all these years.


*Update 5/20/2018*
Well, almost 3 years after my initial review this game is still in early access. They've done some major graphics and UI overhauls, but the game is still garbage. Maybe one day when our kids are old enough to PC game this will see a full release, but I wouldn't hold my breath.

*Original Review 10/16/2015*
Do you like magic?
Have you ever wondered how magicians do their tricks?
Do you want me to teach you a trick?
Step 1: Buy DayZ
*POOF*
Congratulations you just made $30 disappear with absolutely no fucking idea on where it'll ever go! 

Do you think you got a game in return? Psyche! 
What you have purchased is a shoddy, poorly-optimized, lame excuse for an open-world survival game. "But they'll be updating it over time to make it run better, add new features, and fix any in-game bugs". Nope, try again. In the last two years there have been - from what I can recall - about 4-5 major updates. Sure, there have been "bug fixes and balancing" implemented, but the same recurring problems never seem to get fixed. In fact, some of these issues have gotten worse. For example, at initial release a lot of the zombies were bugged; they could clip through walls and doors, hit you from excessive distances, and you would hear sounds of them near you without seeing any followed by taking heavy damage. 

Those bugs don't even include the fact that zombies would chase you for 10-15 minutes at a sprinting pace without stopping. In that time, since the game was so poorly balanced, you would often get messages that your character was dehydrated, hungry, cold, and probably bleeding; but since you're being tailed by zombies you have no chance to remedy the problem. These messages usually continued until your character passed out or you died trying to fight the zombies back. 

Now I'm sure you're thinking, "fighting the zombies back can't be that hard", but the hitboxes are so broken beyond repair that you could swing at a zombie 100 times and probably only hit them about 20 times. The problem with this is that the zombie AI is so overpowered that they'll hit you at least 4-5 times before you even hit them once, and since bleeding starts after one or two hits you have no choice other than to run away or die tryin'.

I could go over so many other issues with the game, but I'm honestly tired of even thinking about the frustrations this game gave me. 

Moral of the story: Don't buy it; it's not worth your time, money, or frustrations. This game will probably never come out of "early Alpha", and if it does the developers are only lying to you and themselves. With the amount of progress this game has seen in the last two years I would be surprised if it gets a full, well-optimized release by the time my grandchildren are born.
I would've rather have spent this money on 20 milkshakes.

So i'm running around on a vanilla server with high population and looting the most player intense areas. I start to fall into a false sense of security. Sure that backpack i just looked was damp..... someone was here recently....whatever.  Those packages were opened on the ground..... strange. I stake out a rook with a rifle for 10 minutes and see nothing. So I decide its time to cook some chicken and eat. I get the wood and start my fire in a house off the main block of town. I cook 1, 2, 3 pieces of chicken. The 4th piece of chicken goes onto the stove and im happily munching down the 3rd.  BANG- fade to black - "You are Dead".   
Shot in the head while cooking chicken, whoever it was crept up from a long way because you can here all types of footsteps in this game. 
10/10- Would get shot in the head cooking chicken again.,

You'll get killed and then to top it off your body will then be eaten by the next hungry naked from the beach. Cannibals Among Us. Over the years, DayZ Standalone has struggled to match the success of the Arma 2: Operation Arrowhead DayZ mod. The change in leadership, attributed to a lack of motivation, has resulted in a failure to prioritize crucial in-game elements, such as basic movement mechanics, weapon handling, and the loot system. Compounding these issues are persistent glitches, like zombies walking through walls and fences, suggesting a neglect of fundamental gameplay mechanics.

It appears that the development team has invested considerable efforts in superfluous features, such as an overly intricate clothing damage system, complex food preparation processes, and an abundance of ways to succumb to natural causes. While these elements may contribute to realism, they seem to overshadow the essential task of establishing a solid foundation for the game.

While mods undoubtedly enhance the gaming experience, the fragmented nature of unofficial servers can be a drawback. Maintaining a consistent player base becomes challenging, leading to periods of low online activity. While this may be a personal preference, the considerable time investment required to configure mods detracts from the seamless experience one expects from a fully released game, exacerbated by the dwindling number of available servers.

The question arises: is it reasonable to support developers who have shown little improvement over the past four years? While individual preferences may vary, the consensus is that the game requires substantial attention and refinement. The concerns expressed echo a sentiment that significant work is needed to bring DayZ Standalone to a level that meets player expectations. This will not happen.

I started playing Dayz mod so I have been playing this game more than 10 years.
This game offers a unique gaming experience that you will not find elsewhere. Somehow the first zombie survival game managed to be the best game of the genre and get things better than most games out there.
The game experience can be catered to your liking with modded servers. Whether you prefer hardcore survival experience where you have to fight for scraps and kill people with a shovel, or a more casual experience where you want to play PvE and build a homestead, or a more ''arcade'' feel where you want to build a base with a clan, do missions, raid other clans bases and carry a 50 cal sniper rifles and PKMs without being overburdened, you can find a server that has exactly the Dayz you will enjoy.

The game has come a LONG way from its alpha, and will be supported further as it is only gaining in popularity.

There are some negatives. The game engine has some drawbacks, due to its scale (250 sq km maps...) and its age and origins. Do not expect Unreal engine graphics here, and be prepared to deal with bugs and clunkyness of the game interface. Your experience may vary depending on the server you play.

Left a positive review a few months back, then I started playing tarkov more in depth. The most redeeming quality about DayZ is the modded servers, and you soon realize that almost every good modded server just tries to emulate what makes tarkov good. Barebones Dayz is no better, it remains a buggy mess and the gameplay loop is horribly repetitive. traveling long distances and surviving the night is about as fun as being on hold for 2 hours because someone in New Mexico bought a tv with your credit card number. 

I am not saying tarkov is a better game, because that has enough problems of its own. But if you want a more rewarding and stable gameplay experience for essentially the same price, I would recommend EFT. 

Of my 400 something hours on this game, about 300 or more was spent running from location to location.

New Review DEC 2023: The leaps and bounds this game has made over five years is minimal. However, the game is solid. The modding community makes this game incredible. Bohemia being left to their own devices on it? Disappointing. It lacks CONTENT updates. Pushing updates with a new gun and some clothes is appalling. It gets a positive review purely based on the fact that modders keep this alive.

Old Review from 2018: Needs more updates, more like a running simulator, however a good laugh with friends after the tedious boring grind to get gear.
THAT GOOD GOOD

To be brief, the game is less finished than the Mod was two years ago. The development team breaks old features faster than they can implement new ones. This game is dead in the water, and likely will never be finished. On the off chance it is ever completed, the game is a far cry from what it was originally sold as; a multiplayer survival game based off a milsim for realism. Instead, what you're getting is deathmatch shooter built in a poor choice of engine. Do not buy.

Edit:
Returning years later, things aren't better. Fewer things are outright broken, but many have been simplified to a point that the content of the game is ultimately just as truncated. The game is a lonely grind up to an unsatisfying PVP experience - too little focus was given to why, and how, players can cooperate. Paired with a clunky interface, jittery NPC's, and limited simulation from a game built off a sim, I can't say much positive about it.

I was really hesitant to buy DayZ for PC.  I played on PS4 in 2019 which was a buggy mess with terrible controls for console.  Playing on PC in 2023 is a completely different experience.  I have personally run into zero bugs in 25 hours of playing and am enjoying the game immensely.  When DayZ is working properly, it is an amazing survival game.  The only rule is to survive however you see fit.  I am enjoying living a hermit's life just fishing and hunting in the woods while avoiding other players.  When I do occasionally come across another player it is really intense, but enjoyable.  I recommend taking the leap and playing if you like survival games.

ehhh, haveen't played it in 2 weeks and starting to feel withdrawal... need to pick it up again

anyway, i've heard it's a great game for hunting the toughest prey, that being other players. cannot help you there as i actually play it on PvE. and everyone knows toughest game are actually squirrels, just ask my dog

so yeah i have heard it can generate adrenaline rushes like no other game. or you can, just for example, find a hunting oriented PvE/roleplay server where you won't get shot on sight. then just set up a base in the wilderness and go hunting for hours while sipping real life whiskey and enjoying a cigar (well a cigarette here as i'm a simpleton). animals are skittish, you hunt by sound and it's pretty relaxing, for me at least. well if it's not your thing there also are servers with fishing mods. not my thing really but well, these mods are made well. and it doesn't hurt that game is rather pretty visually as well

which brings me to modding scene. it's quite big. there's a variety of themed servers to pick from, even though theme on 80% is "kill on sight". but the remaining 20% will have a lower population, well it seems to me at least. perhaps KOS is quite fun, people do say so :D there's a ton of modded maps - Namalsk (sooo cold...), Deer Isle (parkour hell but good otherwise), Takistan (desert with little on it compared to other maps, good for sniping), Pripyat (yeah, that one) and that's just a few. recently played on 2 still not publicly released maps, both work in progress. both quite stunning, really

uh, and there are game mechanics. just check WOBO. i'm 5k hours in and still learning new things every now and then. basics are as follows: wear gloves, stay fed/hydrated, don't get shot/zombie smacked/become wild life food and don't jump off crazy heights. going deeper, you get character health mechanics, bullet speed and drop, bullet damage drop off over distance, other stuff. this game is pretty deep if it comes to it

would not recommend livonia DLC though. devs went out of their way to mess up solo players basically gatekeeping best loot unless you team up with someone. i do have livonia but due to that mechanic i've got no interest in playing it, as i play solo

all in all, would fully recommend. whatever your playstyle, you will find servers for it. even if you're into running around carrying a (modded in) lamp while wearing rather flashily coloured and weird outfit with your pals throw zucchins at other players and one even serving as an on foot speaker for blasting cheesy music. honestly, happened 2-3 years ago and still no idea what was that about... sometimes you just meet weirdos i guess

I am incredibly disappointed in the DayZ project, in which I believed for many years. Many years of hope for its development and growth were shattered in a single day, destroyed by the DayZ team!
I remember the game's initial launch when it struggled to run on mid-range computers. Numerous game errors, server search problems, and even a simple vertical ladder could easily kill your character, putting an end to hours of loot hunting.
Only the community helped pull this project out of the mire, out of the abyss into which the entire DayZ team was rapidly descending. What is DayZ today without all the user modifications, wonderful servers created by the community's hands? Who are you without them? I know how DayZ operates on PlayStation—it's a completely dead game. Thanks to the community that still believes in the game and carries it on its shoulders, but this is not your merit!
And today, when developers can help and support each other, standing firm, the entire DayZ team has turned its back on its colleagues and started mocking the failure of The Day Before team. It's important to mention that the state of the DayZ game at the time of its release was no better, and perhaps even worse, than The Day Before. It's crucial to note that as of 2023, the DayZ team still hasn't learned to properly synchronize vehicles in their game, not to mention numerous other bugs that we all know about.
I am ashamed that I bought your game, and it's hard for me to tolerate the hypocrisy of the DayZ team. I will never return to it, wishing you all the best.

I originally left a review for this game back in 2015 that was Dayz down to the bone: 

"Boring game, just a running simulator. Takes hours to find friends, no maps, cannot spawn near each other. Once you do find each other the game is just plain boring! I hoped it would get better after owning it for 12 months but nothing has changed at all. 

You spawn, you look for loot, you run from zombies you die. Repeat. 

You spawn, you look for loot, you run from zombies, you find other players. You die. Repeat

You spawn, you find lots of loot, guns, food everything you need. Then what? Run around doing nothing until you die. Repeat."

But a lot has changed in the years since then and with modded servers this game finally lives up to what i wanted it to be. I would now recommend this game to everyone.

How it all plays out,

Spawn in,
Loot Up,
Find a cut up human's guts
Get into a fight
Take a hostage
Force the hostage to eat his friend
Watch the hostage slowly die from the illness from eating
Laugh at him
Take more hostages
Die
Repeat

10/10 would do it again
