Original : March 5th 2015:
An amazing game, highly recommended but not for those who can't endure bugs. Remember most games take about 3 years to be fully developed, and under an open-alpha is no different so expect for this game to be in alpha for at least another 9 months or more, but i have to say it's the only open-world survival game i ever play for it's attention to detail and promise of so much more. There are plenty of bugs, but don't let that deter you from purchasing the game now at a reduced price, as this game has more promise than any survival game out there (the forest may be close with it's multiplayer but i still prefer dayz for its large worlds, beauty, and zombies) .

Pros:
-Inventory system in which all clothing has seperate pockets matching real life (kind of arcadey right now as you can put large things in your pants and such)
-Large open world
-no arcadey crap to break immersion
-Deer, elk, pig, goat, chicken, and sheep to hunt the shit out of (first advanced ai stages just recently implemented)
-plenty of mechanics not limited to (and just in their beginning implementations) : growing crafting system for items and weapons alike, hunting, horticulture, lockpicking, a v3s (drivable vehicle), the beginning of a loot respawn and global economy loot system, exciting pvp system thanks to a local voice chat (most "survival mmos lack this for some reason, we need voice to communicate in dire situations if we don't have teamspeak)
-Armbands that can be crafted from raincoats to be used as a realistic way to identify team mates
-Large scale of melee weapons, firearms, and long list of wearable clothing including medic outfit, firefighter, military (many types)
-new battle eye that has *somewhat* stopped hackers, and will always keep getting better
-amazing personal experiences if you stay friendly and know how to cautiously talk to others, many bandit fights.
-lots and lots of features planned to all be added within 2015
-console version coming out, not planned to be "watered down" at all, by the developers words, and i do believe it, noone would buy a crappy watered down dayz
-others daddy cant summarize cuz he's in the clouds

Cons:
-large amount of character killing bugs (mostly involved with connecting to faulty servers , pick a dozen GOOD and STABLE servers you can trust and stick with them
-lag and desync can happen on many servers , try and choose servers closest to your country 
-hackers come and go, but eventually large ban waves are handed out , i personally haven't had any experiences with hackers in my 1,186 hours except for 2 times back in the day when we all had m4's
-rubberbanding occurs on characters on servers experiencing heavy load (lol)
-PVP bandits everywhere, although i have to say out of the many people i see in my travels at least half of them are friendly, the other half shoot on sight , so stay hidden
-high learning curve at first for some, especially learning to avoid certain bugs in certain mechanics (they always get fixed some faster than others)
-vehicles kill you sometimes when you stand next to them on uneven ground or if the engine is on and you get out

All in all its a great game and i highly recommend it because it's given me nearly 1,200 hours of fun already and its only half way finished ! Be patient, if you can't handle the bugs, dont abandon the game just take a break for a month becuase progress is steady!

I keep it installed for one simple reason - it has stood the test of time and continues to have a great community of modders and clans to experience the full potential of open world PVP PVE zombie experience.

Unmatched Open-World Experience: "DayZ" sets itself apart with its massive, beautifully rendered open world. The game's setting, a fictional post-Soviet country named Chernarus, is sprawling and detailed, offering a sense of scale and realism rarely seen in other games. This vast landscape is filled with hidden spots, varying environments, and dynamic weather, providing an incredibly immersive experience.

Survival at its Core: The survival mechanics in "DayZ" are intricate and realistic, making every decision significant. From managing hunger and thirst to treating injuries and illnesses, players must use their wits and resources to stay alive. This level of detail creates a deeply engaging survival experience where every action can mean the difference between life and death.

Unpredictable Player Interactions: What truly sets "DayZ" apart are the player interactions. Every encounter with another player is unpredictable – they could be friendly and helpful, or they could pose a significant threat. This unpredictability adds an exciting and often nerve-wracking layer to the gameplay, making each play session unique.

Continuous Development and Community Support: The developers of "DayZ" are committed to the game, consistently releasing updates and improvements based on community feedback. This ongoing development ensures that the game continues to evolve, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging.

Build, Explore, Survive: Players can craft items, build bases, and explore the world to collect resources. This element of creativity allows players to leave their mark on the world, offering a sense of ownership and accomplishment.

In summary, "DayZ" is a must-play for those who love survival games and enjoy a challenge. Its expansive open world, detailed survival mechanics, and the thrill of unpredictable player interactions create a uniquely engaging experience that keeps players coming back for more. Whether you're navigating the wilderness alone or teaming up with friends, "DayZ" offers an adventure where every decision matters and every moment is memorable.

Here's my opinion on "DayZ' 

                The first thing i want to mention is on the UI, If you are first starting the game there could be some confusions in the UI since there is no true tutorial for the game, But as you play it, it will become more obvious what certain icons do and get used to the Ui.

               The next thing i want to talk about is fps / third person aspect of the game. Although i love third person, in all general i love how immersive the first person offers when it comes to gameplay, The thing i like about this game is that it offers a range of first person / third person only servers to mess around in if you prefer one or another. The shooting / aiming mechanic could also use some work with some bugs but we'll get more into that later. The movement is not the best but for the type of game it is i do think it works well with the mechanics they have in place at this time. 

                 The next thing I'd like to focus on is the modding side of things. The game has extensive modifiable servers to offer hosts and players a wide variety of content, but don't worry if modding isn't your thing there is always vanilla official servers you can always play. 

                  Next i want to focus on some cons of the game that could stray players away. 
First thing is the cheater problem. If you play on official servers then you will almost 90% of the time run into a cheater. Its much better on non-official servers where they are highly moderated by the server hosts. Another con would be there is quite a bit of bugs that could break your immersion, for example: Sometimes when you interact with doors and other intractable things, it will cause your hands to be bugged. Which means most of the time if you don't have a friend to tie you up to fix it, you would have to re log, Another bug would be sometimes when aiming / shooting a fully automatic gun it won't let you hip-fire.

            Finally in the 956 hours I have in the game I overall enjoy its immersive, Game play filled, Modability of the game. Although the bugs are rough sometimes they are the small cons over many pros of the game and I highly recommend playing it if it's your style.

DayZ is undeniably one of my all-time favorite games, and it's amusing how it captured my interest even before I could play it myself. Despite limited playtime due to not having a computer initially and its absence on consoles, I immersed myself in hours of watching role-playing server videos, compelling me to dive into the game when the opportunity arose. My experiences were consistently enjoyable, making it easy for me to recommend DayZ to anyone contemplating whether to give it a try.

Set in a vast map with numerous towns and cities, DayZ offers a rich zombie survival experience. The game's immersive world, although predominantly in a language other than English, can be navigated more comfortably with the help of online maps. As a free-roaming survivor, the game's loot system is rewarding, providing a variety of weapons and crafting options, allowing players to create bases and even drive cars.

However, DayZ truly shines in its PVP aspect. I strongly recommend diving into free-to-play, role-playing, or PVP servers with a group of players for an enhanced experience. Caution is advised, though, as the game's unpredictability can lead to encounters with untrustworthy individuals who may betray your trust, adding an element of realism to the survival dynamic.

Despite potential encounters with eccentric characters, DayZ is a game well worth the investment. Whether you're concerned about the return on investment or the overall experience, don't hesitate. With a couple of years under its belt, the game is likely more affordable now and promises an unforgettable and immersive experience. Give DayZ a shot – you won't regret it.

"DayZ" is an intriguing survival game that places players in a post-apocalyptic world filled with both dangers and opportunities. The game's strengths lie in its realistic survival mechanics, vast open world, and the unpredictable interactions with other players.

What I Liked:

Realism: The need for food, water, shelter, and medical supplies adds an intense realism to the game, making every decision crucial for survival.
Player Interactions: The unpredictability of encounters with other players creates tension and excitement. Cooperation or conflict are equally possible, adding depth to the gameplay.
Open World: The vast map offers diverse landscapes and environments to explore, each with its own challenges and resources.
Crafting and Exploration: Gathering resources to craft items and discovering hidden locations is rewarding and keeps the gameplay engaging.
What I Disliked:

Technical Issues: Occasional bugs, glitches, and server issues can detract from the overall experience.
Steep Learning Curve: For newcomers, the learning curve can be quite steep, leading to frustrations early on.
Recommendation:
For players who enjoy challenging survival experiences and the thrill of unpredictable player interactions, DayZ offers a unique and immersive gaming experience. However, it's important to note that the game may not appeal to everyone due to its technical issues and learning curve. If you're patient and enjoy intense survival gameplay, it's worth giving DayZ a try.

Writing this directly after my first firefight. Playing solo and this game is great. Only 30 hours total so far and the hardest part at first was finding food/drink and figuring out how it all works. Spent my first life cooking and learning that only to get blasted as soon as I left the building I was in. Fires give you away.

Second life, looting a major city to get instantly dropped. 

Third life, die from starvation.

Okay, fourth attempt. Ran around a huge city for a while. Figured out things to leave behind and what to keep. Few dead survivors laying around. Sure, means someone's ahead of me so the tension is on. I enter a house and see briefly a zombie across this small river running oddly as if it was chasing someone. I hear a bullet hit my window. Run out back and get a better angle only to see it was a stray bullet as a few more went flying in different directions. Okay, this guy doesn't know how to aim, I thought. Pull out my bolt action rifle, aim, line it up and I see a second guy right behind him. I don't think they've seen me yet, maybe just luck. I aim at the first guy as he stops in his tracks and pop him right in the head, guy goes down. Can see his mate panicking running around as I re-enter the house to get a different angle and the second guy comes back into view, right next to his mate. Pop the bastard, he goes down. Okay, I thought, let's check it out. As I cross the river I see ANOTHER guy running around towards my direction and back up to the first guys spot. I fire with my pistol, he turns around and returns fire. 3,4 hits and the boy goes down. I'm unscathed. Turns out 3rd guy was actually 2nd guy, don't know how he got back up but oh well. I scope it out a bit more before I start looting then quickly stealing their sub-machine gun, tactical gear and ammo. Firefight is over, I find a spot to log out and contemplate my heartbeat.

So here I sit writing this, hands still shaking and heart calming down. This game provides some adrenaline-filled, intense action and I loved every moment of it. Crafting is a bit tricky, getting the hang of it as you just gotta experiment or spend half the time on the wiki.

Look, this game had one of the roughest development cycles ever, it took a VERY long time to get out of early access and a lot of people gave up on it, I remember the days of avoiding walking on a rock because you could fall through the game, or Zombies appearing out of the floors hah.

They made this longer by changing the game engine halfway through development, BUT this was the best possible idea they could have had, since the Enfusion engine was used, most of the graphical and physics based glitches were fixed.

We then entered the days of loot balancing issues, where you would simply just starve because you literally could find no food at all, the rumours of finding apples in trees was 110% a lie and I'm sticking to that, bullets for guns you never found and the zombies were little more than a slow nuisance. But with trial and error this was all eventually 'fixed' and the 1.0 release date came.

Now the game is smooth as butter, zombies are actually scary and even climb fences to catch you, weapons are in places they should be and food is as scarce as it should be (exists but not in copious amounts) base building and farming were introduced which added a little extra fun and longevity to playing sessions,  honestly there's more in this game now than you could wave a short stick at :D

The actual reason I still play this game after 12 years of rough development hell, poor patches and broken ankles is the sheer adrenaline it gives you when you're fully geared and you start hearing gunshots nearby, or see another group of players also geared up, do you attack, do you avoid? It really gets the blood pumping and i struggle to find games in the vast genre that is 'sandbox survival' that do this as they all kinda mould into one and are just 'meh'

This review as a player has more then 300 hours experience on different accounts. This will be quick and straight to the point 

The games not bad but due to its life cycle and it’s future plans I don’t recommend this game. 

What made this game so popular in the beginning is not because of what it is now. But of rather it’s  atmosphere, exploration, game engine, mili simulation ( built upon mili simu) 

The actual game mechanics of survival can be casually enjoyed but not for long. Base building and crafting are basic and sad considering how much time this game has been in developement. 

The engine now is amazing and a huge improvement. But sadly this is really the only astounding improvement since alpha release.

In an overall review this game can be enjoyed with its casual aspects with a couple friends and enjoy its world exploration. Combat is somewhat average, nothing great. 
The only advantage this game has is to created stories in peoples play throughs. Everything else is just shit. 

There are better games out there that have more to offer. If you have to buy this game just for its historical gameplay go ahead. But you will not be enjoying it as much as other games on the market. 

I do not recommend this game at its price point and it’s progression stages from early access.

It's an incompetently made game. I defended them for years, they were going through an engine rewrite, gamedev is hard etc, but years after release and continuous development, many major updates, you can't put things down without them occasionally disappearing. If your inventory has slots for the thing you're putting away, even if you're replacing a like for like item (eg: weapon mag,) it will just drop on the ground if they're different orientations in inventory. Even sometimes if they're the same. If you take out a, for example,  walkie/GPS (which has its own special inventory slot) with a hotkey, then put it away, the game will ignore that slot and if you have no other space, just drop it on the ground without telling you. Sometimes you'll spawn into the same server you left as an alive character and suddenly be dead for no reason with a new spawn. Walk down a staircase and your character has a seizure. Also - solid objects like walls are often a mere suggestion to the undead. You'll frequently get all the way to military areas, which takes hours, aggro a zombie, and then get kicked because the server can't handle the zombies and loot. But because when you leave your character stays in game for 15s to prevent combat-logging, your character just sits there dying helplessly, even when it's a server frackup, so you die through no fault of your own. which is a common theme

It can be a pretty mellow camping simulator, but the game is objectively bad. They removed the mechanics which change your appearance if you're friendly or a bandit because it's "not realistic" but then added a counter for survivors killed, which besides also not being realistic in game psychology means it's the only thing players can track as a form of progression, so of course they'll see that as "what you're supposed to do." Those together destroy any chance of not being killed on sight. The devs do not understand what made the mod back in the day a global phenomenon, because you could arguably look past the fact that the product straight up does not work because it had a great community which had reasons to actually create interesting human stories more interesting than "saw a guy, killed him". It really sucks if one of the best things in your game was the hackers, especially when you get rid of them and realise that substantially, there's nothing really left. You can learn the mechanics, but in any other game that's the start of actually having fun with it, once you figure it out there's nothing more ... There. Also, half of those mechanics are just outright dumb, while the game is supposed to be realistic above all. Open a tin of beans with dirty hands? Of course you'll get sick, because your character decides the best way to eat a mostly liquid food out of a cup-shaped container is to stick your fingers in like a 4-year-old instead of drinking from the tin like a functioning adult. But just-as-dirty gloves are fine. It's something you can learn fast, but it's one of many examples of "realism" actually being fake difficulty that makes no sense to pad out the time you spend in the game before realising its lack of anything real to offer

Pros: 
Can be mellow and beautiful at times if you want a camping / hunting sim with a chance of being murdered at any time. It's also a good exercise in nihilism and learning to accept and embrace loss as an inevitable part of life 

Cons:
Literally everything else. The game is an indefensible, nonfunctioning PoS. It still plays like a pre-alpha, and they actively turned it into a shooter with crazy long rounds instead of the fascinating survival game that made it famous. Which is a real shame, because they began with a winning formula that I adored and systematically fracked up every part of it. 10 years after they started selling the game, it still doesn't have feature parity with the mod that made it, which would be fine as a conscious design decision, which it famously isn't. A ton of people stan it because it lets you experiment with sadism, killing someone actually affecting something they've been working for for hours or days, so they really feel the loss, which is interesting and has its place, but doesn't excuse the product you pay for being outright broken, and it's the only way anyone you're likely to run into actually plays which gets old fast 

I always eventually come back to this game out of hope, because it had the potential to be more amazing than any other, but I always uninstall it because it's quantifiably bad

This game is a headache all the way from downloading it to playing it. I couldn't even play the game at first when i bought it because it wouldn't load me into any servers. I kept getting kicked before even joining.

Then, the actual gameplay is garbage. The game mechanics are clunky, there are no guides or tips to help you along, everything has a steep learning curve. And there is virtually no loot to find. You'll die of starvation or dehydration before you die from a zombie because there's NO food anywhere.

Clothing mechanics are broken. You could be wearing 5 layers of thick clothes and still shiver in slight winds. The clothing descriptions don't even make sense: the insulation on one pair of pants could be high while the other pair is low, but the low insulation pants will say they're warm while the high insulation pants will say they suck at keeping you warm. So it makes no sense at all.

Edit #2: Since the latest update, zombies are seemingly harder to kill, the radius that they notice you is larger, and connectivity on official servers have degraded. I've been kicked off of servers more times in the last week than I have in all my years of playing on multiple platforms. I am severely disappointed. Although, I still love this game, and would still recommend. 
Now that I have 5 times the amount of hours logged in the game since the time of my initial review, I can properly review the game. I love this game, I'm still somewhat new to the game, there are aspects still lost on me. But that little nugget won't stop me. The opportunities in this game are pretty much limitless. The fact that you can work together in this game with other players, or delve into anarchy (which is the sad majority of servers), is amazing. There are things that can be fixed, like certain animations, the car driving has always been bugged. But I know the Devs are always working hard on this game, to make it better. I highly recommend this game. Happy Scavenging! 
Edit#1: Since my last review (20 Hours) I now have over 120 on PC alone. I also play on console. This game is fantastic and perfect for relaxation. I HIGHLY recommend this game for those who want a post-apocalyptic simulator type game. As always, happy scavenging!

Gameplay Features in DayZ offer a thrilling and immersive experience. The game's open-world environment allows players to navigate through a post-apocalyptic world, where survival is the ultimate goal. The dynamic weather system adds realism, as players must adapt to changing conditions such as rain or fog. Crafting and scavenging mechanics enhance the gameplay, as players must search for supplies to meet their basic needs and defend themselves against both zombies and other players. The game also features a comprehensive health system, where injuries and illnesses can have serious consequences, adding a layer of tension and strategy. Additionally, the freedom to make choices and interact with other players creates a unique and unpredictable gameplay experience. With its realistic and engaging gameplay mechanics, DayZ offers a captivating and rewarding gaming experience.

still trash even after getting used to the game, it becomes boring and stale, not worth the money or dlc, its honestly sad how boring this game is, just waking gathering supplies risking your progress taken away. 3/10 it gets repetitive and a death can set you back doing the same shit over and over again.

I've played this walking simulator for a bit now. You can't get attached to anything, all is temporary. An update, server wipes, or just players looking for you, will leave you back at the coast with nothing. You have to be able to enjoy the early game that is looting and walking 1000m+ just to get a little foothold. 

My most memorable moments have been my interactions with other players through voice chat, getting kills against all odds, noticing my improvement on reflection, and, most recently, finally healing from influenza which affected me for 4+irl hours and then getting shot by a Mosin while thinking "the guy I shot at earlier is probably watching, he was stack-" .

3. Even after deleting and unsubscribing to mods, the non modded servers will still somehow detect the mods that you previously loaded and will not allow you to play on that non modded server?!?! There are mods you can load that are not for any specific server, and yet after loading them you can't use them on a non modded server, very baffling to me. 

4. Game frequently lags. 

5. Weird & annoying door glitch in this game. Sometimes when I'm being chased by a zombie and run into a building or house and try to shut the door, I might get stuck inside the door and then can't move and then I can't fight off the zombie, in which case I get killed.

One of the best games I've played. I like COD, Apex, Fortnite, PUBG, etc... But, this game is NOT a fast paced Deathmatch. It is a hyper-realistic zombie post-apocalyptic survival PvP game. It can be Vanilla and you battle against PvE with some PvP sprinkled in or it can be heavily modded with no zombies and mainly PvP for faster pace. You DIE a lot... You cannot win at this game. There is no trophy. Your mission is to survive as long as possible and make that one life a great one. Each life changes drastically to player encounters to loot possibilities. Maps are huge and can take 1hr+ real time to cross. This game is only for the hardest of hard gamers. You will suffer, you will sweat, you will yell, your heart will feel like its popping out of your chest. I have played for years and I still get huge adrenaline rushes with encounters. If you think you can take the hardest survival situations and flourish while battling zombies and players, then I welcome you to experience this game.

I have been playing DayZ since the Arma Mod days and immediately picked up the stand alone version almost 10 years ago! The developers did the right thing and rewrote the core game play engine. It was sometimes a bumpy ride but now you have a very fun game, easily my favorite game of all time. You never know what's going to happen. Sometimes you are killed without seeing the other player(s), sometimes you are the killer. Other times you meet up with friendly players and have a little adventure. The fear, paranoia, and immersion this game generates is unmatched. Incredible game, highly recommended!

People are asking for refunds but the game clearly states: WARNING: THIS GAME IS EARLY ACCESS ALPHA. In game and on the store page. You know what you paid and the game is not "dead" It's been actively updated constantly.
It's aight.

First of all, to stay alive, the character must look for food and water in abandoned buildings and be sure to provide warm clothes. If you don't dress warmly, you'll get sick, and in order to recover you'll have to drink 2-3 tablets of tetracycline and warm yourself by the fire for a long time.
In addition, there is a risk of being killed as other players and zombies, and even wild animals such as bears, wolves, or poisoned food or dirty water, for this also need to watch out. Each disease has its own symptoms.

The open world of the game is a 225 square kilometers area, with many cities, villages, fields and forests and many interesting places from bunkers to lonely houses in the woods, which are very coolly drawn without any internal barriers and downloads.
Almost every building in the game can be entered. Most of them have loot spawn points, even in high-rise buildings.
Created a separate system of building bases. You can build up almost all the houses 
Or just make a hidden shelter from the branches in the woods. You can bury caches.

In general, the game is very interesting as a standalone survival and team play. 
In my opinion, one of the best

All I can say is, too much fun. It's Alpha currently, however still a blast to play. If your looking for that "Gritty" post-apocalyptic survival MMO then you might want to give DayZ a shot. DayZ Mod is also a game I fancy obvioulsly for the simple fact that it has more content right now. Patience is what we need to give the developers of this fine game. And it seems with each passing update the content improves. Give DayZ a try, it will change you...

2018 edit... Well after multiple years in the works, Dayz finally hit beta is in fact a game worthy of a second try.

2021 edit... Still going strong

2023 edit... Still by far my favorite survival game, very nostalgic to me.
